{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} {{DISPLAYTITLE: 2010 ''Tonight Show'' conflict}} [[File:Conan O'Brien and Jay Leno.jpg|thumb|310px|Late-night talk show hosts [[Conan O'Brien]], left, and [[Jay Leno]], right, talk on the set of ''The Tonight Show'' in 2009.]] The '''2010 ''Tonight Show'' conflict''' was a media and [[public relations]] conflict involving American television network [[NBC]] and two of its then-[[late-night talk show]] hosts, [[Conan O'Brien]] and [[Jay Leno]]. Leno, the host of long-running franchise ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' since 1992, and O'Brien, host of ''[[Late Night (NBC)|Late Night]]'' since 1993, were strong ratings leaders for the network for much of the decade. When O'Brien's contract neared its end and he was courted by other networks in 2001, NBC extended his contract and guaranteed him he would be the fifth host of ''The Tonight Show''. The network neglected to let Leno know this until his contract extension in 2004, when they informed him he would remain host for five more years and then transition the show to O'Brien in 2009. When that time arrived, other networks conveyed interest in Leno; NBC, in an effort to keep both of its late-night stars, offered Leno a nightly primetime show before the local news and O'Brien's ''Tonight Show''.
''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]'' and ''[[The Jay Leno Show]]'' failed to attract immediate viewers, and NBC affiliates, seeing their viewership decline, grew restless. [[NBCUniversal]] CEO [[Jeff Zucker]], alongside chairman [[Jeff Gaspin]] and executive [[Rick Ludwin]], created a remedy: move Leno back to his 11:35 pm start time and bump O'Brien a half-hour later, to 12:05 am. O'Brien and his staff were both disappointed and furious; when it became clear O'Brien would not agree to the proposed changes, the situation grew heated. Though not a breach of either host's contract, the change resulted in a public outcry and public demonstrations largely in support of O'Brien. O'Brien's public statement that he would "not participate in the destruction of ''The Tonight Show''" led to negotiations with NBC for a settlement. O'Brien and his staff received US$45 million to walk away from the network, with his final ''Tonight Show'' airing January 22, 2010; Leno was reinstated as host that March, while after a contractual seven-month ban on appearing on television, O'Brien moved to [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] to host ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''.
The controversy surrounding the scheduling move and the reinstatement of Leno was described by media outlets as "embarrassing" for the network and a "public relations disaster".<ref name="wsj11910">{{cite news |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704541004575011482898148788?mod=WSJ_hpp_MIDDLTopStories |work=The Wall Street Journal |first1=Sam |last1=Schechner |first2=Shira |last2=Ovide |first3=Lauren A.E. |last3=Schuker |title=NBC to Pay $40 Million to Show Conan O'Brien the Door |date=January 19, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref name="abc11510">''[[ABC News]]'' article: "[http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=9575927 NBC's Talk Show Wars Seen as PR Disaster for All]".</ref>
==Background== [[File:NBC logo.svg|thumb|upright|[[NBC]] remained a late-night ratings leader for years prior to the conflict.]] On May 22, 1992, [[Johnny Carson]], host of NBC's ''The Tonight Show'' for nearly 30 years, retired from the program at the age of 66. The network signed [[Jay Leno]], Carson's "permanent guest host", to become the program's fourth host upon Carson's exit. Carson clearly held the view the position should be given to [[David Letterman]], host of his own program, ''[[Late Night with David Letterman|Late Night]]'', which had directly followed Carson's ''Tonight Show'' for ten years. NBC tried to appease both stars, but Letterman left the network in a very public conflict that resulted in the creation of his own competing show on CBS, which began in 1993. ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', "the first truly substantial competing franchise to ''Tonight''", regularly won in the Nielsen ratings against Leno for two years, "proving for the first time that late-night television—and the profits that came with it—could exist beyond ''The Tonight Show''."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=27}}
Leno's ''Tonight Show'' started rocky; prior to Letterman's move, NBC considered matching CBS's offer to allow Letterman to take over from Leno.<ref name="hr1">{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jay-lenos-tonight-show-battles-431265|title=''Tonight Show'' Battles: a Timeline of Contending Hosts|author=Brandon Kirby|date=March 27, 2013|publisher=''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''|accessdate=February 7, 2014}}</ref> Letterman beat Leno for nearly two years until August 1995, when Leno welcomed [[Hugh Grant]], who had recently been arrested for soliciting a [[prostitute]] ("What the hell were you thinking?", Leno asked, to applause), to a previously-booked appearance on ''Tonight''. From that point on, Leno beat Letterman in the ratings, and ''The Tonight Show with Jay Leno'' remained number one for the next 14 years (for Leno's entire run).
NBC chose to continue the ''Late Night'' franchise, and at the suggestion of ''Saturday Night Live'' producer [[Lorne Michaels]], hired [[Conan O'Brien]], a relatively unknown writer for ''SNL'' and ''[[The Simpsons]]'', to take over the time slot beginning in late 1993. ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' was constantly at risk for cancellation in its early years; at one low point in 1994, NBC threatened to put him on a week-to-week contract. Executives were anxious to replace him with [[Greg Kinnear]], who followed O'Brien with ''[[Later (talk show)|Later]]'' at 1:30 am., but Kinnear left to pursue a career in acting later on.<ref name="NewYorkT" /> Interns filled empty seats in the audience while affiliates began to inquire about replacement hosts.<ref name="nymag1">{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/arts/features/14575/index3.html|title=Conan on the Couch|author=David Bianculli|date=September 26, 2005 |publisher=''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''|accessdate=December 21, 2012}}</ref><ref name="shales2">{{cite news|title=So I Was Wrong ... Late Night's Late Riser|author=[[Tom Shales]]|date=June 18, 1996|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=Aug 27, 2013|url=http://nbckicks.tripod.com/riser.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010094505/http://nbckicks.tripod.com/riser.html|archivedate=October 10, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Things improved for the show slowly (mostly revolving around O'Brien's performance) and by 1996, O'Brien's audience, largely young and male (a coveted demographic), grew steadily and the show began to beat competitors in the ratings, which it would continue to do for 15 years.<ref name="NewYorkT">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/24/magazine/24Conan-t.html?pagewanted=all |title= Heeeere's ... Conan!!! |author=Lynn Hirschberg |date=May 20, 2009 |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|accessdate=December 21, 2012}}</ref>
Another notable episode of O'Brien's tenure at the show came when Letterman asked to appear as a guest and say some kind words to him.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3oksYO5TV48</ref> O'Brien considered this the turning point that changed everything for him, which he mentioned while paying tribute to Letterman in an opening monologue of [[Conan (talk show)|his own talk show on TBS]], which aired the same night as Letterman's final show; O'Brien notably asked his viewers to turn him off and watch Letterman later on in the monologue.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tV7NC0DGgVg</ref>
==Early history==
===Contract renewals (2001–04)=== Near the turn of the millennium, NBC's late-night lineup—Leno at 11:35, O'Brien at 12:35, and ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' on the weekend—remained a leader in the ratings.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=27}} By 2001, O'Brien's contract at NBC had less than a year left to run, and despite arguably "coming into his own" in the preceding years, the network was reluctant to pay him on the same scale as other late-night hosts.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=28}} That year, competing network [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] mounted an "extended, comprehensive campaign" to lure O'Brien away from the network, viewing his style suitable for the network's image—"young, hip, somewhat subversive".{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=28}} [[News Corporation]] chairman and CEO [[Peter Chernin]] pursued O'Brien personally, taking him and executive producer Jeff Ross to dinner on several occasions. Fox's plan involved making O'Brien the network's signature star: his program would begin 30 minutes before Leno's and Letterman's (the network's local news broadcasts aired earlier than other networks, allowing the head start) and he would receive cross-promotion via its [[Animation Domination|animated division]] and on [[Fox NFL|Sunday NFL games]].{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=28}} Chernin also offered the host seven times his current pay (a jump from US$3 million to US$21 million).{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=29}} Ross, friends with NBC president and CEO [[Jeff Zucker]], informed him that Fox was aggressively pursuing O'Brien; NBC returned with a more realistic offer, bumping up O'Brien's salary to US$8 million and renewing him through 2005.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=30}}
While many of O'Brien's professional advisors and managers pushed for the Fox deal, O'Brien's desire to one day perhaps take over ''The Tonight Show'' after Leno made it a difficult decision (O'Brien, like many comedians, had grown up idolizing Carson's incarnation).{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=29}} Chernin warned O'Brien that waiting around for Leno to leave would be "only an invitation to long-term disappointment, and potentially a path toward undermining a promising career."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=29}} Nevertheless, O'Brien signed the deal with NBC in March 2002; the contract extended him through 2005 and most significantly contained an "explicit [[Prince of Wales]] clause" that solidified the official line of succession: If anything were to happen to Leno, O'Brien would step in.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=31}} O'Brien's successful hosting job at the 2002 [[54th Primetime Emmy Awards]] "sent out the most resounding message yet about his growing strength as a performer",{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=32}} and a year later, NBC broadcast O'Brien's tenth anniversary special in primetime.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=33}} By the time Leno's contract again came up for renewal, a discussion would be needed regarding the future of ''The Tonight Show''. Facing the prospect of attempting to keep both Leno and O'Brien, Zucker made the final call on Leno's deal: "Yes, we'll extend your deal. But this is your last contract. Time to hand over the keys."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=38}} The plan would extend Leno four additional years, after which he would give ''The Tonight Show'' to O'Brien.
In February 2004, NBC executive Marc Graboff informed Ross of the conversations, and he in turn ran the idea of waiting four more years to O'Brien, who was immediately receptive.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=39}} Zucker, along with top late-night executive [[Rick Ludwin]], met with Leno in March at his [[The Burbank Studios|Burbank]] studio to discuss the contract extension, and explained the network's stance on handing over the show to O'Brien.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=42}} While Leno quietly felt both disappointed and befuddled, he noted he did not want to see himself and O'Brien go through the same dilemma he and Letterman faced twelve years earlier, and agreed to the plans.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=42}} His only request was that NBC wait to announce O'Brien's installment as host well after the extension, to which the executives agreed.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=43}} While Leno handled the news professionally (to Zucker's relief), he soon headed to ''Tonight Show'' producer Debbie Vickers' office to let her know he felt as if he had just been fired.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=43}} NBC's announcement of the renewal inevitably led to press speculation on O'Brien's fate; to that end, O'Brien and his team went with the charade, peppering interviews with unclear, vague statements on his future.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=44}} On September 27, 2004, O'Brien officially signed on to become the next host of ''The Tonight Show''; NBC allowed the first comment aside from the press release to come from Leno on that night's show.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=45}}<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/27/business/media/28CND-NBC.html | accessdate =April 4, 2010 | work=The New York Times | first=Bill | last=Carter | title=Conan O'Brien to Succeed Jay Leno in 2009, NBC Announces | date=September 27, 2004}}</ref> "'Cause this, you know, this show is like a dynasty," Leno said. "You hold it, and then you hand it off to the next person. And I don't want to see all the fighting and all the 'Who's better?' and nasty things back and forth in the press. So right now, here it is—Conan, it's yours! See you in five years, buddy!"{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=46}}<ref name="Conan1">{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6115643/|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|title=Leno promises smooth transition to O'Brien|date=September 28, 2004|accessdate=May 12, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080421162830/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6115643/| archivedate=April 21, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="Conan2">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/27/leno.obrien/|publisher=CNN|title=O'Brien to replace Leno on 'The Tonight Show'|date=September 27, 2004| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
===Losing Leno (2005–08)=== [[File:Jeff Zucker, CEO of NBC Universal.jpg|200px|thumb|left|[[Jeff Zucker]], former CEO of [[NBCUniversal]], was at the forefront of the conflict.]] Leno was, in reality, overcome with incredulity; in private conversations, he likened the situation to a relationship, noting that he was loyal and still ended up "heartbroken".{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=68}}{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=70}} From his perspective, the situation made no sense, as they had remained number one in ratings and consistently brought in money.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=70}} He began frequently lamenting his confusion to producer Vickers, explaining that he was "sick of lying" when people inquired on his retirement.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=85}} Eventually, he began mulling over his options after ''Tonight'', telling his staff that after the transition, they could simply move to [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] and work at the [[Walt Disney Studios (Burbank)|Disney lot]] not far from their current Burbank studio.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=86}} His frustration with the situation came across in his nightly monologues, as more jokes regarding NBC's fourth-place position in the ratings, as well as jokes regarding the future transition, began to appear.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=86}} While NBC executives tended to not worry in the immediate years following the decision, by 2007 Zucker began to ponder what losing Leno might mean for the network.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=87}} Around this time, Fox and ABC began to court Leno privately, conveying interest and holding discreet conversations.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=89}}<ref name="NewYorkT" />
More offers for Leno had sprung up (including a lucrative one for a [[broadcast syndication|syndicated]] program by [[Sony Pictures Television]]), and in early 2008, Zucker began to make trips to the Burbank studio in an effort to keep Leno.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=110}} He gave him numerous suggestions, including a [[Bob Hope]]-type deal (high-profile specials), a Sunday night primetime show, or even a nightly cable show on [[USA Network]] (owned by [[NBCUniversal]]).{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=111}}<ref name="NewYorkT" /> Executives began to entertain an ideal solution—pay off O'Brien and retain Leno—but Zucker viewed the idea as "outrageous".{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=112}} By this time, NBC had already broken ground on a new studio for O'Brien's ''Tonight Show'', renovating Stage 1 at the [[Universal Studios|Universal lot]] in [[Universal City, California|Universal City]], for a reported US$50 million.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=100}} During a spring lunch meeting with Jeff Ross, NBC sports chief [[Dick Ebersol]] advised that O'Brien retire silly antics (such as his signature "string dance") and focus more on pitching his show to middle America, which would involve stretching out his monologue.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=104}} O'Brien, then a year away from inheriting the sacred ground of ''The Tonight Show'', was indeed lengthening his monologue, but viewed suggestions from Ludwin as largely unnecessary: "I think people are overthinking the twelve-thirty-to-eleven-thirty shift", he said, instead desiring to put his own stamp on the show's tradition.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=115}} By this point, O'Brien's popularity, sky high at the time of the contract signing, had gone down slightly. He had opted not to change his act to suit a more mainstream audience (as NBC imagined he would), and CBS's [[Craig Ferguson]], who occupied the post-Letterman slot, had begun to occasionally trump O'Brien in overall ratings.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=119}} Though internal anxiety increased among executives, most tended to still support O'Brien.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=119}}
Zucker's last resort for Leno was a nightly 10 pm program.<ref name="NewYorkT" /> As ratings had slipped entirely for 10 pm shows on NBC, he imagined a nightly Leno at 10 could perhaps produce a "paradigm shift" and reverse NBC's fortunes.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=119}} On December 8, 2008, Leno verbally agreed to stay at the network—producing a nightly 10 pm variety show titled ''[[The Jay Leno Show]]''—and phoned ABC and Fox to inform them.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=127}}<ref name="10pmleno">{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/CA6620935.html|title=Jay Leno Taking Over 10 P.M. On NBC|publisher=BroadcastingCable|accessdate=December 9, 2008}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Zucker and Ludwin planned to meet with O'Brien later to explain the deal, but as word leaked out to ''[[The New York Times]]'', they decided to meet with him directly following that night's show.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=128}} Following the meeting, Ross and O'Brien met with writers and mulled over the decision. O'Brien instantly felt uneasy, but as he was still in essence receiving ''The Tonight Show'', he remained calm.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=130}}<ref name="NewYorkT" /> ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' officially signed off the following February, followed by ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' on May 29.<ref>Elber, Lynn (May 14, 2009). [http://www.buffalonews.com/entertainment/story/671373.html Leno's last `Tonight' guest is Conan O'Brien]. Associated Press via The Buffalo News. Retrieved May 14, 2009.</ref> Much of O'Brien's entire staff moved cross-country to Los Angeles to prepare his version of ''The Tonight Show''.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=132}} He and his staff threw themselves into developing the program, but remained concerned regarding NBC's commitment—or lack of one.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=133}} Meanwhile, senior level executives at NBC predicted the Leno experiment would flop wildly, getting trumped by hour-long dramas on competing networks and cable.<ref name="NewYorkT" />
In announcing his 10 pm show on ''The Tonight Show,'' Leno said, "People are asking me, 'What are you going to do after the last show? Are you going to go on vacation?' This kind of stuff. Actually, I'm going to a secluded spot where no one can find me: [[NBC]] primetime. As most of you know, we're not really leaving. We're coming back at 10 o'clock in September. It's a gamble. It's a gamble. I'm betting everything that NBC will still be around in 3 months! That is not a given!"<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QnK40x6Nqlw</ref>
==Ratings==
===''The Tonight Show'' and ''The Jay Leno Show'' debut===
''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]'' pulled in over nine million viewers to its June 1, 2009 premiere, doing extremely well in the coveted young demographics.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=141}} Critics were generally very favorable; [[Tom Shales]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'', once a Conan detractor, wrote that "There's every indication that O'Brien will be up to the job of his illustrious predecessors."<ref name="shales">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/02/AR2009060200566.html|title=TV Review: Tom Shales on Conan O'Brien's ''Tonight Show'' Debut|author=[[Tom Shales]]|date=June 3, 2009|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=February 8, 2014}}</ref> Older audiences, however, gradually checked out of the program night by night; seven episodes later, the ''Late Show with David Letterman'' had edged above O'Brien for the first time.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=141}}<ref name="nydailynews20090807">{{cite news | title=Inner tube: David Letterman beats Conan O'Brien for fourth week | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2009/08/07/2009-08-07_inner_tube_david_letterman.html | publisher=[[nydailynews.com]] | date=August 7, 2009 | location=New York | first=Richard | last=Huff| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> While Zucker called O'Brien to reiterate that the generational change was expected, other executives were not as pleased. O'Brien and his team were not happy with the lack of promotion in the show's early weeks.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=142}} Against the wishes of several PR executives, Zucker authorized a press release proclaiming O'Brien "the New King of Late Night", a move that attracted ridicule. Zucker later regretted the decision, and many at O'Brien's ''Tonight Show'' offices were displeased.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=143}}
Over the following weeks, Zucker grew weary with O'Brien's performance and what he regarded as a booking of the wrong stars.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=147}} When a controversy erupted over a joke Letterman told regarding politician [[Sarah Palin]]'s family, Zucker eagerly pushed the O'Brien camp to bring her on their show, eyeing an opportunity to regain viewers and perhaps make it a turning point for a show not doing particularly well.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=151}} O'Brien disliked the idea, finding it pandering to viewers that would alienate fans and the press, as well as hurt his relationship with Letterman. "This reaction drove Zucker nuts", wrote Bill Carter in ''[[The War for Late Night]]''.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=151}} "As a producer, he knew how to manipulate audiences—that was simply what you did as part of the job. [ ... ] As a boss, he couldn't believe Conan would stand in the way of what was obviously the smart business move—for him and his network."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=151}} Meanwhile, Letterman continued to score higher ratings than O'Brien with regularity; his fall interview with President [[Barack Obama]] topped ''The Tonight Show'' by over 2.6 million viewers, and the next week, [[David Letterman#Extortion attempt and revelation of affairs|a scandal]] involving attempted [[extortion]] and personal affairs made him the talk of the country.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=183}}<ref name="mediapost20090903">{{cite web | title=Conan Ratings Take Swing At Letterman | url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/index.cfm?fa=Articles.showArticle&art_aid=113000 | publisher=mediapost.com | date=September 3, 2009 | accessdate=28 June 2010 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> By August, ''The Tonight Show'' was still losing to Letterman in total viewers, but, owing to O'Brien's appeal to a young audience, maintained its lead in the touted demographics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/08/20/late-night-old-letterman-beats-new-conan/|title=Late Night: Old Letterman Beats New Conan|last=Carter|first=Bill|work=Media Decoder Blog|access-date=2017-11-09|language=en}}</ref>
Meanwhile, Leno was candid regarding his plans for his new show: "Even though it's ten o'clock, we're going to pretend it's eleven thirty."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=169}} ''[[The Jay Leno Show]]'' premiered on September 14, 2009, featuring [[Jerry Seinfeld]] and [[Kanye West]] (just following his infamous rant against [[Taylor Swift]] at the [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards|MTV Video Music Awards]]) as guests. The program racked up 18.4 million viewers, doing much better than O'Brien's ''Tonight Show'' debut in both overall numbers and young demographics.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2009/09/tv-ratings-the-jay-leno-show-debuts-to-17-million-plus.html | title=TV ratings: 'The Jay Leno Show' debuts to 17 million-plus | publisher=Zap2It | accessdate=September 15, 2009 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090918183843/http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2009/09/tv-ratings-the-jay-leno-show-debuts-to-17-million-plus.html | archivedate=September 18, 2009 | deadurl=yes | df=mdy-all }}</ref> Some critics were harsh to Leno's program, with many viewing it as a rehash of the show he had just left. Mary McNamara of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called a commercial funnier than the show's whole, saying, "This is the future of television? This wasn't even a good rendition of television past."<ref name="latimes">{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/sep/15/entertainment/et-leno15|title=''Jay Leno Show'' stays on familiar ground|author=Mary McNamara|date=September 15, 2009|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|accessdate=February 8, 2014}}</ref> By the show's second week, with it airing directly opposite season premieres, ''The Jay Leno Show'' saw its audience size fall to six million viewers.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailyfinance.com/2009/09/25/why-nbcs-not-sweating-lenos-falling-ratings/ | title=Why NBC's not sweating Leno's falling ratings | publisher=DailyFinance | accessdate=September 28, 2009 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091002234913/http://www.dailyfinance.com/2009/09/25/why-nbcs-not-sweating-lenos-falling-ratings/# | archivedate=October 2, 2009 | deadurl=yes | df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="tvbtn">TVbytheNumbers article: "[http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/11/04/how-did-nbc-do-at-10pm-weekdays-before-the-jay-leno-show/32641 How did NBC do at 10pm Weekdays Before The Jay Leno Show?]." Retrieved November 4, 2009.</ref> As the weeks wore on, producer Vickers noticed that NBC's plan—to save the best segments, such as Leno's signature "Headlines", for last in order to provide a strong lead-in for local news—was possibly hurting the program.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=179}} One month in, Leno often only made third place, and executives became more uneasy.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=184}}
===Slipping numbers=== Ratings for NBC affiliates' local news broadcasts at 11 began to slip by mid-October, especially on NBC [[owned-and-operated station]]s in the largest markets, creating high anxiety for the network.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=184}}<ref name="lat101909">{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/oct/19/business/fi-ct-nbc-affils19 |work=Los Angeles Times |first=Joe |last=Flint |title=Jay Leno's new time slot wreaks havoc for NBC affiliates |date=October 19, 2009 |accessdate=28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> ''The Tonight Show'' still retained a slightly higher share of the coveted 18–24 demographic against Letterman, but saw those numbers slip even more when ''The Jay Leno Show'' began.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=185}} Affiliates began to complain, and in addition to a [[domino effect]] on the local news, O'Brien, and ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' (O'Brien's successor at 12:30), the disastrous ratings for Leno had damaged NBC's existing primetime lineups.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=186}}<ref name="nymag61857">{{cite web|title=Will Somebody Please Save NBC? |url=http://nymag.com/news/media/61857/ |last=Harris |first=Mark |work=[[New York Magazine]] |date=November 8, 2009 |accessdate=December 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112180010/http://nymag.com/news/media/61857/ |archivedate=November 12, 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> This cascading effect caused by the lowered 10 pm lead-in was so significant that local news viewership fell an average of twenty-five percent nationwide, with the decline in some markets being as high as fifty percent.<ref name="50percent">{{cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/jay-leno-and-conan-obriens-on-air-battle/ |work=The Associated Press|title=Jay Leno and Conan O'Brien's On-Air Battle |date=January 14, 2010 }}</ref> By November, two months after the debut of ''The Jay Leno Show'', ratings for ''The Tonight Show'' were brought down "roughly two million viewers a night year-to-year" from when Leno hosted the program.<ref name="msnbc33808107">{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/33808107/ns/entertainment-television//|title=Is Leno's 10 p.m. experiment nearing an end?: Low prime-time ratings also pulling down local news, 'Tonight' numbers|last=Brioux|first=Bill|date=November 9, 2009|publisher=[[msnbc.com]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091111122548/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/33808107/ns/entertainment-television/|archivedate=November 11, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no|accessdate=December 2, 2009}}</ref> Clearing the 10 pm time period for Leno also damaged relations with the producers of shows that previously occupied that slot, such as ''Law & Order: SVU''{{'s}} [[Dick Wolf]].{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=186}} Leno offered an October 29 interview to ''[[Broadcasting & Cable]]'', which included a notable exchange on the possibility of ever returning to the 11:35 slot: "If it were offered to me, would I take it? If that's what they wanted to do, sure. That would be fine if they wanted to."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=187}} Industry trades were abuzz over the 11:35 comment, and when Conan sidekick [[Andy Richter]] called the move less than "classy" in a chat with [[TV Squad]], Leno called Ludwin to complain.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=187}}
As most programs went into repeats in December, the staff at Leno, notably Vickers, had focused on grabbing big-name guests for that month in an effort to save the show; these efforts were cut short when she was informed they had "until the end of November".{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=189}} Affiliate calls came at an alarming rate,{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=190}} and research analysis revealed O'Brien's drastically reduced median age for ''The Tonight Show''—age 56 to 46—could possibly reflect that he was too "niche" for the earlier time.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=191}} Any effort to take Leno off the air was halted by his contract, which had an enormously unusual catch in that Leno had signed a "pay-and-play" contract (as opposed to the usual "pay-or-play") guaranteeing NBC would both air his program and pay him for up to two years.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=190}} On November 6, NBC chairman [[Jeff Gaspin]] received an email from the sales division with a suggestion to cancel O'Brien and reinstate Leno as host of ''The Tonight Show''.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=189}} Upon Gaspin's legal interpretation of Leno's contract, the option to simply move Leno back to ''The Tonight Show'' became relevant.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=190}} When very poor ratings came in for the November "sweeps" period, affiliates became persistent and board members demanded something be done regarding the 10 pm lead-in.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=192}}
If something were not done by January, the affiliates reasoned, they would instate syndicated programming or move up their news broadcasts and pre-empt Leno.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=192}} Desperate for a decision, Ludwin, Gaspin, and Zucker kicked around possible solutions for their dilemma, such as cutting Leno to a few nights per week.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=193}} In an attempt to alleviate the situation, Vickers moved the most popular comedy segments to the second act of ''The Jay Leno Show'', moving their "10 at 10" segment to later in the broadcast.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=193}} Gaspin again received the suggestion to put Leno back at 11:35, and soon began working on a plan to cut ''The Jay Leno Show'' to a half-hour, leading into Conan's ''Tonight Show'' around midnight.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=195}} From their perspective, the biggest casualty in this scenario would be ''Late Night with Jimmy Fallon'', which would get bumped to 1 am.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=195}} The reconfigured lineup could start in March 2010, following NBC's coverage of the Winter Olympics.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=196}} Zucker preferred a plan for Leno to include an occasional guest and comedy piece, while Dick Ebersol favored returning to the way it once was, with Leno at 11:35 and O'Brien at 12:35.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=199}} Gaspin laid out his plan to Zucker one week before Christmas, but both agreed to wait it out for the new year, as to not "ruin anybody's holiday season".{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=196}}
==Conflict==
===Proposed changes=== {{quote box|align=right|width=30em|quote=It struck Conan that Jay had played it well, in his passive-aggressive way, and wound up winning again. And maybe, in contrast, he himself had simply played it all wrong.|source= —Bill Carter, ''[[The War for Late Night]]''{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=223}}}}
The plan moved forward after confirmation that O'Brien's contract did not guarantee a strict 11:35 start time (a loophole included primarily to accommodate sports pre-emptions and specials such as [[New Year's Eve with Carson Daly|the network's New Year coverage]]).<ref name=unsocial>Carter, Bill. (October 20, 2009) [http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2010/12/late-night-wars-excerpt-201012?currentPage=all The Unsocial Network | Culture]. Vanity Fair. Retrieved on December 17, 2010.</ref>{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=200}} Gaspin planned to disclose the news to Leno first, and then, if all went well, report it to O'Brien the next week.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=198}} When Gaspin met with Leno and Vickers and laid out the proposal, the response was positive, although they questioned how such a plan would work.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=200}} Gaspin reasoned that the company was in a desperate position, and he indicated his confidence that O'Brien would too go along with the changes.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=200}} While Leno embraced the plan, Vickers was unnerved; without a guest or music act she might have no [[studio audience]], which could have disastrous consequences for Leno.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=203}} In order to meet with O'Brien the following Monday, Gaspin was forced to cancel a meeting with the affiliate board, but promised them that by doing so, he would have an answer to the 10 pm problem that would "likely be something [they'd be] happy with".{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=205}} Following his January 6 show, O'Brien met with manager Gavin Polone and lamented his anxiety with the ratings: "I just think [Leno] is going to hurt me in some way."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=205}}
News regarding Leno leaked to FTV Live by the following morning,{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=206}} which set the Internet abuzz with rumors regarding both Leno's and O'Brien's fates.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=207}}<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2010-01-10-leno-over_N.htm | work=USA Today | first=Gary | last=Levin | title=After failed Leno experiment, a redefining moment at NBC | date=January 11, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref name="nyt">{{cite news|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/07/update-nbc-plans-leno-at-1130-conan-at-12/ |work=The New York Times |first=Bill |last=Carter |title=Update: NBC Plan Would Move Leno Back to Late Nights |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710074608/http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/07/update-nbc-plans-leno-at-1130-conan-at-12/ |archivedate=July 10, 2010 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref> Gaspin scheduled an immediate meeting with Ross and O'Brien as soon as they arrived and explained the proposed changes. "I know how hard I worked for this", responded O'Brien. "It was promised to me. I had a shitty lead-in."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=210}} Following the tense 15-minute meeting, O'Brien and Ross returned to the ''Tonight'' studio. [[TMZ]] reported on the story with a headline reading, "NBC Shakeup; Jay Leno Comes Out on Top."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=211}} O'Brien called an emergency staff meeting and assured all that they had not been canceled and all would be fine.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=211}} The TMZ story deeply bothered O'Brien ("the timing of the leak to TMZ—coming so soon after a story that Jay had been canceled—screamed of an attempt at diversionary action"), and he and Ross reasoned that they indeed were the last to be told of the changes.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=212}}
By the following morning, both men determined that they would have to leave NBC,{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=215}} and O'Brien opened that night's show with "We've got a great show for you tonight—I have no idea when it will air, but it's gonna be a great show."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=216}} Polone viewed the move as a reactionary one by Zucker, concluding that he was acting in self-preservation, since NBCUniversal owner [[General Electric]] (GE) was in the process of negotiating the sale of a controlling interest in the company to cable operator [[Comcast]].{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=252}} When a story ran that night on ''The New York Times'' website that Fox had an "overt interest" in O'Brien and was not going along with the plan,<ref name="nyt 010810">{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/09/arts/television/09leno.html | work=The New York Times | first1=Bill | last1=Carter | first2=Brian | last2=Stelter | title=NBC's Shift in Schedule May Be Up to O'Brien | date=January 9, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Zucker reasoned that Polone was to blame.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=217}} The situation became heated when Zucker placed a call to O'Brien's agent, Rick Rosen, inquiring on the story and demanding an immediate answer from the O'Brien camp.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=217}} Gaspin spoke on the situation at a previously scheduled press conference that Sunday, noting that "I obviously couldn't satisfy either with 100 percent of what they wanted. That's why I came up with this compromise."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=219}} Zucker, upon hearing that O'Brien still did not take the proposal well, threatened Rosen, saying "I'm going to tell you right now that I can [[Guarantee (filmmaking)|pay him or play him]]. I can [[non-compete clause|ice]] you guys."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=220}} On the following Monday's show, O'Brien continued jokes on the subject; responding to thunderous applause, he joked, "You keep that up, and this monologue won't start until 12:05."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=222}}
==="People of Earth"=== Rosen suggested they hire "perhaps the best known (and most feared) litigation lawyer in Hollywood", Patty Glaser, to help grasp the situation.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=218}} Following discussions on Leno's contract during a post-show conference, Glaser turned her attention to O'Brien for his opinion. He expressed his desire to write a statement expressing his feelings on the matter, and after hearing what he would possibly say in such a statement, Glaser agreed to the idea, although Ross was initially reluctant.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=224}} O'Brien went without sleep that night, crafting his statement obsessively.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=224}} He returned to the studio the following morning, listening as the lawyers and Glaser read over the statement (it remained largely unchanged before publication).{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=225}} According to ''The War for Late Night'', Glaser found "the statement as ideal for their purposes. It laid out Conan's point of view unequivocally, but without compromising his legal options. Nothing in there overtly said he was quitting, so he could not be accused of forsaking his contractual obligations."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=225}}
O'Brien's press release went out mid-day on January 12, which he addressed to "People of Earth":
<blockquote>For 60 years the ''Tonight Show'' has aired immediately following the late local news. I sincerely believe that delaying the ''Tonight Show'' into the next day to accommodate another comedy program will seriously damage what I consider to be the greatest franchise in the history of broadcasting. ''The Tonight Show'' at 12:05 simply isn't the ''Tonight Show''. [ ... ] So it has come to this: I cannot express in words how much I enjoy hosting this program and what an enormous personal disappointment it is for me to consider losing it. My staff and I have worked unbelievably hard and we are very proud of our contribution to the legacy of ''The Tonight Show''. But I cannot participate in what I honestly believe is its destruction.<ref name="nyt11210">{{cite news | url = http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/12/conan-obrien-says-he-wont-do-tonight-show-following-leno/?src=twt&twt=nytimestv | work=The New York Times | title=Conan O'Brien Says He Won't Host 'Tonight Show' After Leno | date=January 12, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref name="msnbc11210">[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/34827830/ns/entertainment-television Conan Won't Do "The Tonight Show" Following Leno], ''MSNBC.com'', January 12, 2010</ref></blockquote>
According to ''The War for Late Night'', "the 'People of Earth' letter—the manifesto, as NBC came to call it—changed the tone. This wasn't just Conan saying no; it was Conan saying no, and you're wrong, and, by the way, go fuck yourselves."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=229}} However, the moment that "represented the point of no return" came that Wednesday night, as a "clearly liberated" O'Brien joked in his monologue that "I'm trying very hard to stay positive here, and I want to tell you something. This is honest. Hosting ''The Tonight Show'' has been the fulfillment of a lifelong dream for me. And I just want to say to the kids out there watching: You can do anything you want in life. Yeah, yeah—unless Jay Leno wants to do it, too."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=235}} Following the joke, Leno called Gaspin, asking, "Why the fuck am I giving up a half hour for this guy?"{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=236}} Conversations changed to focus on what O'Brien would require to resolve the matter, and parties began to discuss a settlement.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=230}}
==Reaction and media coverage==
===Public support for O'Brien=== [[File:Im With Coco.jpg|right|thumb|180px|The "I'm With CoCo" poster was widely circulated online and at rallies during the conflict.]] Public reaction was overwhelmingly in favor of O'Brien during the conflict; in the days following the switch announcement, 88% of related [[Twitter]] posts expressed support for O'Brien.<ref name="mashable">Mashable article: "[http://mashable.com/2010/01/12/conan-obrien-statement/ Conan Wins the Hearts and Minds of the Internet]".</ref> Over one million people joined the two most prominent [[Facebook]] groups supporting O'Brien: "Team Conan" and "I'm With Coco" (referring to an on-air [[nickname]] applied to O'Brien during his ''Tonight Show'' reign).<ref name="nytsupport">{{cite news|last=Stelter|first=Brian|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/14/arts/television/14fans.html|title=In Leno vs. O'Brien, Fans Show Allegiance Online|work=The New York Times|date=January 14, 2010|page=C1| accessdate=June 28, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Artist Mike Mitchell designed a poster reminiscent of the [[Barack Obama "Hope" poster|Obama "Hope" poster]], depicting O'Brien superimposed with an [[American flag]] in the background with the caption "I'm With Coco". The poster was widely circulated and displayed on the web and at various rallies. The color [[Orange (color)|orange]] also became the choice of color for fans of Conan, referencing his light orange hair.<ref name="elephant">Elephant Journal article: "[http://www.elephantjournal.com/2010/01/im-with-coco-the-poster-the-facebook-page-viva-la-grassroots/ I’m with Coco. The Poster. The Facebook Page. Viva la Grassroots]."</ref> O'Brien's overnight ratings began to shoot up (much to NBC's chagrin), and the viral support for O'Brien only increased by the week of his final shows.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=242}}
Rallies in support of O'Brien were organized outside NBC studios across the United States, notably in [[Los Angeles]], [[Chicago]], [[Seattle]], and [[New York City]].<ref name="shinyobjects">{{cite news | url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/shinyobjects/2010/01/im_with_coco_storms_chicagos_nbc5_with_conan_obrien_protest_monday_night.html | work=Chicago Sun-Times | first=Craig | last=Newman | title=I'm with Coco storms Chicago's NBC5 with Conan O'Brien protest Monday night | date=January 18, 2010 | accessdate=28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot--> | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329114950/http://blogs.suntimes.com/shinyobjects/2010/01/im_with_coco_storms_chicagos_nbc5_with_conan_obrien_protest_monday_night.html | archive-date=March 29, 2010 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }}</ref> O'Brien briefly appeared at a January 18 rally outside the ''Tonight Show'' studio,<ref>{{cite web |author=Jay Leno |url=http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/insider/2010/01/18/get-your-rally-on/ |title=Tonight Show Insider – Get Your Rally On! 18 January 2010 |publisher=Tonightshowwithconanobrien.com |date= |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100121042312/http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/insider/2010/01/18/get-your-rally-on/ |archive-date=January 21, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> after which he gave the crowd free [[pizza]].<ref name="laist11810">LAist article: "[http://laist.com/2010/01/18/photos_rally_for_conan_draws_hundre.php Photos: Rally for Conan Draws Hundreds, Conan Arrives with Free Pizza] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100121143345/http://laist.com/2010/01/18/photos_rally_for_conan_draws_hundre.php |date=January 21, 2010 }}."</ref> The show's announcer [[Andy Richter]] and drummer [[Max Weinberg]] also made an appearance during the rally to speak to the crowd from atop the ''Tonight Show'' studio, and [[The Basic Cable Band|Tonight Show Band]] trombonist [[Richie Rosenberg|Richie "La Bamba" Rosenberg]] was driven around the crowd in a [[Popemobile]]-style vehicle.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118013963.html?categoryid=14&cs=1&ref=bd_tv|title=Leno: It's 'business'|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=January 18, 2010|author=Schneider, Michael|accessdate=January 19, 2009}}</ref> [[American Red Cross]] representatives were at a number of the rallies to collect money for the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|Haiti earthquake]] relief.<ref name="seattlepi">''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' article: "[http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/archives/191397.asp Seattle Conan fans to rally at Westlake Center]".</ref><ref name="inquisitr">Inquisitr article: "[http://www.inquisitr.com/57688/conan-rally/ Team Conan rallies in protest 'for Coco']."</ref>
Many in Hollywood expressed support for O'Brien, including [[Roger Ebert]],<ref name="EbertSupport" >[[Twitter]] post by Roger Ebert: "[https://twitter.com/ebertchicago/status/7681902025 I agree: A touching statement from Conan.]"</ref> [[Sarah Silverman]],<ref name="silverman">''[[Access Hollywood]]'' article: "[http://www.accesshollywood.com/sarah-silverman-declares-shes-literally-team-conan-offers-advice-to-leno_article_27790 Sarah Silverman Declares She’s ‘Literally’ Team Conan, Offers Advice To Leno]".</ref> [[Will Ferrell]],<ref name="tmzferrell">[[TMZ.com|TMZ]] article: "[http://www.tmz.com/2010/02/20/will-ferrell-sorry-jay-leno-im-calling-in-sick/ Will Ferrell – Sorry Jay Leno, I'm Calling in Sick]."</ref> [[Jim Gaffigan]],<ref name="gaffigan">Twitter page for [[Jim Gaffigan]]: "[https://twitter.com/jimgaffigan/status/7688244856 I'm on #teamconan Team Conan Please RT]."</ref> [[Jeff Garlin]], [[Jim Carrey]], [[Aziz Ansari]], [[Jonah Hill]], [[Seth Rogen]], [[Paul Rudd]], [[Paul F. Numerous media outlets offered support of O'Brien, such as [[Gawker]] and ''The Examiner'', as well as less usual outlets such as advertisements running on [[Adult Swim]]. Numerous parody videos appeared on sites like [[YouTube]] and [[Funny or Die]] in favor of O'Brien.

http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-leno-backlash16-2010jan16,0,4645138.story | work=Los Angeles Times | first1=Scott | last1=Collins | first2=Matea | last2=Gold | title=Taking on America's 'nice guy' | date=January 16, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref name="wsj11510">{{cite news | url = https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/01/15/why-some-comics-arent-laughing-at-jay-leno-essay/ | accessdate =June 28, 2010 | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Nathan | last=Rabin | title=Why Some Comics Aren't Laughing at Jay Leno (Essay) | date=January 15, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100723162841/https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/01/15/why-some-comics-arent-laughing-at-jay-leno-essay/| archivedate=July 23, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2010/SHOWBIZ/TV/01/15/leno.conan.reputation/ | work=CNN | title=Has Leno lost his nice guy appeal? | date=January 15, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref name="kc11810">''[[Kansas City Star]]'' article: "[http://www.kansascity.com/238/story/1691791.html Jay Leno is Mr. Nice Guy no more — but was he ever?]".</ref> Critics [http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/285694 Jay Leno in 2004: "In '09, Conan, it's yours"]</ref> Actor and comedian [[Patton Oswalt]] was among the first celebrities to openly voice disappointment web|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/thedishrag/2010/01/rosie-odonnell-is-on-team-conan.html|title=Rosie O'Donnell is on Team Conan|publisher=[[Zap2it]]|date=January 14, 2010|author=Porter, Leno before and following the timeslot change announcement;<ref name="stern">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZ2fZH2XqNw "Rosie O'Donnell Slams Jay Leno (Part 1 of 2)"]; [[YouTube]]; January 14,
