2010</ref> The [[67th Golden Globe Awards]], which aired on NBC during the heat of O'Brien's settlement negotiations on January 17, featured numerous jokes on the controversy by [[Tina Fey]] and [[Tom Hanks]], as well as show host [[Ricky Gervais]] who quipped "Let's get on with it before NBC replaces me with Jay Leno."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=241}}
Additional criticism stemmed from the fact that the circumstances O'Brien found himself in recalled a similar dilemma that faced Leno toward the end of 1992. Only months into his hosting job on ''The Tonight Show'', NBC considered reversing their decision to choose Leno over Letterman. Leno was aghast and angry that NBC refused to exhibit clear commitment to him as the franchise's new host, and expressed this disappointment publicly. He also made explicit that he would leave the network if he was asked to move back an hour to accommodate Letterman, saying "I'm not going to do some little happy hour from Omaha at 12:30." <ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/23/arts/jay-leno-criticizes-nbc-on-tonight-cliffhanger.html |publisher=The New York Times |title=Jay Leno Criticizes NBC On 'Tonight' Cliffhanger |date=December 23, 1992}}</ref>
Commentators also faulted Leno for what they perceived as a disingenuous attempt on the host's part to forge an "everyman" persona in the way he carried himself throughout the controversy. During the episode of ''The Jay Leno Show'' that aired after it was made public that Leno had been offered the 11:35 time slot back, Leno portrayed himself as an ingenuous employee merely following NBC's instructions, making a point of stating "I don't have a manager, I don't have an agent" and referring to his preference of making direct, "handshake" deals.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.mediaite.com/tv/dont-blame-me-leno-addresses-late-night-mess-head-on/|publisher=Mediaite|title=Don't Blame Me! Leno Addresses Late-Night Mess Head On| date=January 18, 2010}}</ref> Despite his claim of having no representation, Leno retained an agent (Steve Levine of International Creative Management<ref>{{cite news | url = http://gulfnews.com/business/sectors/media/nbc-s-tonight-show-cuts-staff-leno-takes-pay-cut-1.1063683|publisher=Gulf News Media|title=NBC's Tonight Show cuts staff, Leno takes pay cut| date=August 19, 2012}}</ref>), a publicist,<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/12/jay-leno-revenge-of-the-everyman|publisher=Vanity Fair|title=JAY LENO: REVENGE OF THE EVERYMAN |date=December 15, 2008}}</ref> and entertainment lawyers.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://abovethelaw.com/2010/01/what-does-the-conan-leno-nbc-debacle-mean-for-entertainment-law/|publisher=Above the Law|title=What Does the Conan-Leno-NBC Debacle Mean for Entertainment Law?|date=January 21, 2010}}</ref>
Comedian [[Bill Burr]] found that Leno's ambition to take back ''The Tonight Show'' was less objectionable than his "passive-aggressive" behavior and the "powerless" public image Leno put forth instead of "owning up" to his maneuverings. Burr argued that NBC "never gave [Conan] ''The Tonight Show''" in terms of network support, saying, "When Jay got ''The Tonight Show'', he didn't have to follow Johnny [Carson] bombing for an hour. [ ... ] Leno struggled for eighteen months before he got going, and he got to go on after a hit show."<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G9ZsYJLHfBo|publisher=YouTube|title=Bill Burr-Conan O'Brien Last Tonight Show| date=January 26, 2010}}</ref>
Comedian Jeff Garlin accused NBC of being "cheap", suggesting that the network tempted O'Brien with his dream job of hosting ''The Tonight Show'' because they did not want him to go to a competitor, but neither did they want to match what the competitors were offering. Garlin accused Leno of undermining O'Brien's incipient ''Tonight Show'' by taking the 10 pm slot. Garlin stated that while Leno had been nice to him over the years, the host displayed "no character" by taking the timeslot back. Garlin vowed never to appear on Leno's ''Tonight Show'' thereafter.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.tmz.com/2010/03/16/jay-leno-conan-obrien-jeff-garlin-tonight-show-nbc-radio-interview/|publisher=TMZ|title='Curb' Star Rips Jay Leno: He's Got No Character| date=March 16, 2010}}</ref>
In an essay for the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', [[Nathan Rabin]] wrote that Leno had "raced past the reviled likes of [[Dane Cook]] and [[Carlos Mencia]] on the list of popular stand-ups hated by comedians and comedy writers."<ref name="wsj11510"/> Bill Zehme, the co-author of Leno's autobiography ''Leading with My Chin'', told the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', "The thing Leno should do is walk, period. He's got everything to lose in terms of public popularity by going back. People will look at him differently. He'll be viewed as the bad guy."<ref name="latimes11510-2">{{cite news | url = http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-leno-backlash16-2010jan16,0,4645138.story?page=2 | work=Los Angeles Times | first1=Scott | last1=Collins | first2=Matea | last2=Gold | title=Taking on America's 'nice guy' | date=January 16, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> [[Joe Queenan]] from the ''Wall Street Journal'' went further in his criticism of Leno, jokingly comparing the controversy to [[German occupation of Czechoslovakia|Adolf Hitler's annexation of Czechoslovakia]].<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704375604575023132215883398?mod=WSJ_latestheadlines | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Joe | last=Queenan | title=NBC Will Regret Appeasing Leno | date=January 25, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
[[David Letterman]] was one of the more adamant critics of NBC and Leno's handling of the conflict. He noted that, "We went through our own version of this, 17, 18 years ago",<ref name="letterman11510">''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' clip: "[http://www.cbs.com/late_night/late_show/video/?pid=9jBgKjnj8VRTp7FwIvsOK8icPTJ7Dzpb&vs=Big%20Show%20Highlights&play=true David Letterman – Will Jay Leno Do The Right Thing?]".</ref> and he ridiculed Leno's recent "state of the network address", wherein Leno pleaded for viewers not to "blame Conan", with Letterman noting, "In the thousands and thousands of words that have been printed about this mess, who has blamed Conan?"<ref name="lettermanvj">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z-8LGTVF3_I "Dave responded to Jay's 'Don't Blame Conan'"] [[YouTube]]; January 19, 2010</ref><ref name="ct12010">{{cite news | url = http://newsblogs.chicagotribune.com/towerticker/2010/01/conan-jay-david-letterman-blame-nbc-fiasco-mess-catastrophe-debacle.html | work=Chicago Tribune | title=Letterman on Leno's speech: 'He said we should not blame Conan ... and I said to myself no one is blaming Conan!' | date=January 20, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref name="mtv12010">''[[MTV News]]'' article: Anderson, Kyle. [http://newsroom.mtv.com/2010/01/20/david-letterman-nbc/ "Conan O'Brien, David Letterman Continue To Hammer NBC And Jay Leno"] [[MTV]]; January 20, 2010</ref>
[[Jon Stewart]] of [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart|The Daily Show]]'' reflected on the controversy, saying, "At least we don't have to deal with [[Jeff Zucker]]. That guy's like the [[Dick Cheney|Cheney]] of television, [[Dick Cheney hunting incident|shooting shows in the face]]."<ref name="tfp11710">''[[Chattanooga Times Free Press]]'' article: [http://timesfreepress.com/news/2010/jan/17/nbcs-slide-tvs-heights-late-night-punch-line/ NBC'S slide from TV's heights to a late-night punch line]".</ref> Stewart also shouted "Team Conan" as his "Moment of Zen" at the end of the January 21 episode of ''The Daily Show''. [[Stephen Colbert]] of [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' asked guest [[Morgan Freeman]] to read a list of "untrustworthy things", one of which paraphrased a statement made by Leno in 2004, "Conan: The 11:30 slot? Yours."<ref>''[[Colbert Report]]'' episode: "[http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/261286/january-11-2010/morgan-freeman January 11, 2010]."</ref> [[File:Jimmy Kimmel as Jay Leno.jpg|thumb|Fellow late-night host [[Jimmy Kimmel]] performed an entire show in character as Leno.]] At ABC, [[Jimmy Kimmel]] of ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' donned a gray wig and fake chin, performing his entire January 12 show in character as Leno. With his bandleader Cleto Escobedo parodying Leno's bandleader [[Kevin Eubanks]], Kimmel started out his monologue with "It's good to be here on ABC. Hey, Cleto, you know what ABC stands for? Always Bump Conan." He also referenced the "People of Earth" letter, noting how O'Brien declined to participate in the "destruction" of ''The Tonight Show'', commenting as Leno that "Fortunately, though, I will! I'll burn it down if I have to!"{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=233}} Leno called Kimmel the next morning to discuss the bit, and at the end of the call, Leno suggested Kimmel come over and appear on his show. When his booking department called to confirm his appearance on a "10 at 10" segment (during which Leno asked 10 questions to a guest appearing remotely via satellite), Kimmel agreed immediately.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=235}} When he received the questions for his January 14 appearance—such as "What's your favorite snack junk food?"—he realized Leno intended to neutralize the scathing parody and paint the two as friends.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=237}}
Kimmel, however, was upfront with wanting to discuss the fiasco at hand, and during his appearance attempted to steer the questions that way; when asked about his favorite prank, he responded, "I think the best prank I ever pulled was, I told a guy once, 'Five years from now I'm going to give you my show.' And then when the five years came, I gave it to him and I took it back, almost instantly."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=238}} Later in the segment, when Leno asked, "Ever order anything off the TV?" Kimmel replied, "Like when NBC ordered your show off the TV?"<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jcKpf6k3j5I</ref>
Following similar remarks to more questions, Kimmel closed the segment with this comment: "Listen, Jay. Conan and I have children. All you have to take care of is cars! We have lives to lead here! You've got eight hundred million dollars! For God's sakes, leave our shows alone!"{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=238}} Leno never fought back and accepted the bit as comedy (he ascribed it as Kimmel attempting to score some publicity), but producer Vickers was furious.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=239}}
Kimmel discussed the appearance during an interview with [[Marc Maron]] for the latter's [[WTF with Marc Maron|podcast]] in 2012. Kimmel stated that he felt O'Brien was not given a proper chance, but that he was also motivated by his own history with Leno. According to Kimmel, Leno had some years prior been in serious discussions with ABC about the possibility of jumping ship from NBC. During this period, Leno initiated a friendship with Kimmel, wanting to ensure that they would be on good terms if the move was made. (Under that scenario, Leno would have taken Kimmel's time slot and become his lead-in.) However, after Leno made the arrangement to remain at NBC, "those conversations were gone," according to Kimmel. Realizing that Leno's relationship with him had been artificial, Kimmel felt "worked over," reasoning that Leno was using the ABC discussions as a bargaining tactic to try to get his old job back.<ref>[http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episodes/episode_249_-_jimmy_kimmel "Episode 249 – Jimmy Kimmel"]. ''[[WTF with Marc Maron]]''; January 30, 2012</ref>
===Neutrality of Jimmy Fallon=== The only late night host who remained neutral was [[Jimmy Fallon]], calling O'Brien and Leno "two of my heroes and two of my friends".<ref name="hp11410">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/14/jimmy-fallon-weighs-in-on_n_423548.html "Jimmy Fallon Weighs In On Conan/Leno Drama"] ''[[Huffington Post]]''; January 14, 2010</ref> He later joked that, "There's been three hosts of ''Late Night'': David Letterman, Conan O'Brien, and me. And if there's one thing I've learned from Dave and Conan, it's that hosting this show is a one-way ticket to ''not'' hosting ''The Tonight Show''." Ironically, Jimmy Fallon was selected to replace the retiring Jay Leno as host of ''The Tonight Show'' in February 2014.<ref name = "hp11411">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/03/jimmy-fallon-to-take-over-tonight-show-official_n_3007684.html "Jimmy Fallon To Take Over 'The Tonight Show' From Jay Leno In Spring 2014"]. ''[[Huffington Post]]''; April 3, 2013</ref>
===Defense of Leno and criticism of O'Brien=== The comedians who came out in defense of Leno were far fewer and tended to have a professional or personal relationship with the host. Speaking to ''The Hollywood Reporter'', [[Jerry Seinfeld]] rebuffed the idea that NBC deserved blame and chastised O'Brien for pointing fingers:
<blockquote>"What did the network do to him?" Seinfeld asked. "I don't think anyone's preventing people from watching Conan. Once they give you the cameras, it's on you. I can't blame NBC for having to move things around. I hope Conan stays, I think he's terrific. But there's no rules in show business, there's no [referees]."<ref name="seinfeld">{{cite news |url=http://www.thrfeed.com/2010/01/jerry-seinfeld-conan-has-nothing-to-complain-about.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304225011/http://www.thrfeed.com/2010/01/jerry-seinfeld-conan-has-nothing-to-complain-about.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 4, 2010 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |title=Jerry Seinfeld: Conan has nothing to complain about |date=January 10, 2010 }}</ref></blockquote>
The irony of Seinfeld's stance was noted by at least one publication, as ''[[Seinfeld]]'' had itself weathered a rocky beginning thanks to the patience of NBC executive [[Rick Ludwin]], the benefit of a strong lead-in (''[[Cheers]]''), and years to develop its audience as opposed to O'Brien's six months.<ref name="seinfeldcritic">{{cite news |url=http://www.stereogum.com/1771932/shut_up_jerry_seinfeld/vg-loc/videogum/ |work=Stereogum |title=Shut Up, Jerry Seinfeld |date=January 11, 2010}}</ref>
[[Jim Norton (comedian)|Jim Norton]], who was a frequent contributor to Leno's shows, touched on the controversy repeatedly in interviews and on ''[[Opie and Anthony|The Opie & Anthony Show]]'', calling the harsh criticism of Leno "amazing" and suggesting that Leno declining to walk away after stating otherwise was no worse than O'Brien "actually trying to force Jay out by telling the agents, 'If Conan doesn't get ''The Tonight Show'', he's leaving the network.'"<ref name="nortonavcub">{{cite news|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/jim-norton-talks-about-the-art-of-offensive-comedy-81923 |work=The AV Club|title=Jim Norton talks about the art of offensive comedy |date=June 29, 2012}}</ref>
NBC executives served as Leno's chief defenders, with [[Dick Ebersol]], chairman of NBC Universal Sports, being particularly aggressive. Calling Leno's detractors "chicken-hearted and gutless," he summarized the late night situation as an "astounding failure" by O'Brien and further characterized O'Brien's and Letterman's barbed jokes about their rival as "professional jealousy." Addressing the common point about Conan's weak lead-in hurting his ability to build an audience in a different timeslot, Ebersol dismissed it as a "specious argument."<ref name="ebersol">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/15/business/media/15conan.html |work=The New York Times |title=Executive leaps to Leno's defense |date=January 14, 2010}}</ref>
In an interview with Marc Maron that summer, O'Brien's longtime sidekick [[Andy Richter]] noted the contradiction between Ebersol's comments and the actions of the network. The demonstrable impact of ''The Jay Leno Show'' on the ratings of local news across the country was the direct cause of the cancellation of ''The Jay Leno Show'', and gave lie to Ebersol's implication that lead-ins are irrelevant. Leno's ''Tonight Show'', in contrast, had always enjoyed healthy lead-ins courtesy of a strong NBC primetime line-up.<ref name="richterwtf">{{cite news |url=http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episodes/episode_89_andy_richter |work=WTF with Marc Maron Podcast |title=Episode 89 – Andy Richter |date=July 20, 2010}}</ref> Furthermore, the network would have reportedly faced a US$150 million penalty in order to release Leno from his contract, making O'Brien the far less expensive host to get rid of.<ref name="150million">{{cite news |url=https://nypost.com/2010/01/20/conans-32m-leap-for-joy/|work=The New York Post |title=Conan's $32m leap for joy|date=January 10, 2010}}</ref>
Leno himself was among O'Brien's harshest critics, calling O'Brien's numbers "destructive to the franchise" despite O'Brien's success in the advertiser-friendly demographics combined with his significantly smaller salary.<ref name="lenooprah">{{cite news |url=http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2010/01/affiliates-executives-screwed-up-tonight-show-leno-tells-oprah.html|work=Chicago Tribune |title=Conan 'destructive' to 'Tonight Show' and media 'unfair,' Leno tells Oprah |date=January 28, 2010}}</ref> Moreover, Leno's assessment of O'Brien's performance less than three months prior had been significantly different: "Personally, I think Conan is doing fine. He's beating Dave in the demo, maybe not in the popular one right now because Dave has a lot of other things going that have people watching for whatever reason, so I think that's not really a fair thing. It's a little too early to tell."<ref name="lenofine">{{cite news |url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/programming/jay-leno-talks-back-exclusive-interview-bc/35687/ |work=Broadcasting & Cable |title=Jay Leno Talks Back: An Exclusive Interview With B&C|date=November 2, 2009}}</ref>
==Settlement==
===Negotiations=== Discussions neared completion regarding a financial settlement by January 14, and were expected to be in place following O'Brien's final week of shows—January 18–22—a concession O'Brien pushed to give his program a proper farewell.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=240}} Movement on the settlement slowed when run by General Electric (GE) executives, then-owners of NBCUniversal. NBC had several requests, among those that he not bring [[Howard Stern]] on the show his final week (which the O'Brien camp found slightly comical), and that they see the show's final week of scripts (which O'Brien never sent).{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=240}} Talks for much of the rest of the week went nowhere, and a Saturday ''[[New York Post]]'' story ran claiming that O'Brien's staff felt "betrayed" by his actions. The article claimed that the staff did not understand why O'Brien could not just take the 12:05 slot in order to keep their jobs, and that he was instead controlled by his ego. O'Brien was infuriated by the story—which he assumed to be a direct plant from NBC—as nearly all of his staff agreed he should walk.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=240}} He was personally appalled that the network challenged his character, as stressing severance for his employees was enormously important to him (he had paid them out of his own pocket [[2007–2008 Writer's Guild strike|during the writer's strike three years earlier]]).{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=240}}
NBC added more requests, which the O'Brien camp refused as unreasonable, such as the right to pull any of his final shows if the network objected to the content (e.g., a joke about the conflict/NBC).{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=241}} [[Jeffrey Immelt]], GE chairman, questioned why they were paying so much for a performer destined to run to another network.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=241}} Negotiations continued into O'Brien's final week; he could not confirm on-air it was indeed his final week of shows, which produced difficulty in booking the guests he desired for his final show.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=245}} On January 19, multiple media outlets reported that O'Brien and NBC were close to signing a deal between US$30 and US$40 million for the host to walk away from the network.<ref name="ew11910">''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' article: "[http://news-briefs.ew.com/2010/01/19/report-conan-getting-40-million-to-walk-from-nbc/ Report: Conan getting $40 million to walk from NBC]".</ref><ref name="nypost11610">{{cite news |url = http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/nbc_near_deal_to_allow_conan_to_M1LlLoGAkxW4oLZS73jzTO |work=New York Post |title=NBC near deal to allow Conan to leave network |date=January 18, 2010 |accessdate= 28 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="cst11910">[http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/television/1999598,conan-leno-staff-negotiation-nbc-011910.article] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122070546/http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/television/1999598%2Cconan-leno-staff-negotiation-nbc-011910.article |date=January 22, 2010 }}</ref> Following his January 20 episode, O'Brien remained at the studio until the early hours of the morning, alongside Ross and the legal counsel, trying to finalize the settlement. O'Brien wandered off, playing his guitar alone and stepping out on the deserted Universal lot at midnight, attempting to make sense of the situation.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=245}} O'Brien signed the agreement that night and the following day the terms were made public.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=246}}
In all, O'Brien received a US$45 million deal to leave NBC.<ref name="bbc12110" /> O'Brien received pay for the remaining two years of his contract (amounting to US$33 million), with additional payments to Jeff Ross, Andy Richter, and bandleader Max Weinberg.<ref name="nola012110">{{cite news | url=http://www.nola.com/tv/index.ssf/2010/01/conan_obrien_signs_departure_d.html |title=Conan O'Brien signs departure deal with NBC |author=Walker, Dave | newspaper=[[The Times-Picayune]] | date=January 21, 2010 | accessdate=January 21, 2010| archiveurl= https://archive.is/20100126084903/http://www.nola.com/tv/index.ssf/2010/01/conan_obrien_signs_departure_d.html |archivedate=January 26, 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref> The severance pay for his staff was above standard GE levels (amounting in all to US$12 million), which O'Brien had stressed.<ref name="abc12110-2" /> O'Brien paid around 50 stagehands and various crew members at least six weeks severance pay out of his own pocket, as NBC gave those particular staffers nothing in the settlement.<ref name="nydn">{{cite news | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2010/02/02/2010-02-02_conan_obrien_paying_salaries_of_former_staffers_left_out_of_nbc_deal__report.html | location=New York|date=February 2, 2010|title=Conan O'Brien paying salaries of former staffers left out of NBC deal|work=Daily News| accessdate= 10 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The [[International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees]] said that they were "very happy" with how O'Brien treated his employees during the conflict.<ref name="nydn" /> The contract contained a clause prohibiting O'Brien from making negative remarks about NBC for a certain amount of time;<ref name="abc12110-2">''[[ABC News]]'' article: "[http://abcnews.go.com/Business/nbc-confirms-deal-conan-obrien-speeds-nbc-show/story?id=9621682&page=2 Conan's Payback: How Much Did O'Brien's Bugatti Stunt Cost NBC?]" – Page 2.</ref><ref name="ff12010">''Fairfield Mirror'' article: "[http://fairfieldmirror.com/2010/01/20/conan-o%E2%80%99brien-likely-to-sign-40-million-exit-deal-with-nbc/ Conan O’Brien Likely to Sign $40 Million Exit Deal with NBC]".</ref> it did not, however, contain the previously rumored "mitigation clause", in which NBC would be able to keep some of the severance pay after O'Brien found a new network.<ref name="abc12110-2" /> It stipulated that he could return to television on another network no earlier than September 1, 2010.<ref name="bbc12110">{{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8472865.stm |work=BBC News |title=Talk show host gets $45m pay-off |date=January 21, 2010 |accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref name="abc12110-2" />
===Final week=== [[File:I'm With Coco - Supporters.JPG|thumb|Supporters of Conan O'Brien rally outside [[Universal Studios]] in [[Los Angeles]]|alt=A gathering crowd where some people wear orange and hold signs that say "I'm With Coco".]] The conflict only provided more comedy material for O'Brien's ''Tonight Show'' during its final episodes. Among other bits, O'Brien put the show up for sale on [[Craigslist]] ("Guaranteed to last for up to seven months; designed for 11:35, but can easily be moved!"), and then himself; looked back at clips from the show's seven-month tenure that were dubbed "Classic ''Tonight Show'' Moments"; and designed a bit to seem as though he were spending absurd amounts of NBC's money, such as customizing a [[Bugatti Veyron]], playing audio and video clips with expensive rebroadcast rights, and using a purported "rare ground sloth" to spray Beluga caviar on what was presented as an original Picasso.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=244}} Because the segments aired in days immediately following the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]] while national fundraising efforts (including some spearheaded by NBC) were ongoing, O'Brien received criticism for wasting resources. In response to the outcry over the expense of these sketches, O'Brien explained that the segments were indeed jokes, and many of the props were either [[counterfeit]]s or borrowed in exchange for promotional consideration.<ref>{{Cite episode |title=Episode #1.146 at Hulu |episodelink= |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/122598/the-tonight-show-with-conan-obrien-fri-jan-22-2010#s-p1-so-i0 |series=The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien |serieslink= |credits=Ross, Jeff (producer) |network=NBC |airdate=January 22, 2010 |season=1 |seriesno= |number=146 |minutes=8}}</ref>
The guest roster for O'Brien's final show on January 22—[[Tom Hanks]], [[Steve Carell]] and original first guest [[Will Ferrell]]—was regarded by O'Brien as a "dream lineup"; in addition, [[Neil Young]] performed his song "[[Long May You Run]]" and, as the show closed, was joined by [[Beck]], Ferrell (dressed as [[Ronnie Van Zant]]), [[Billy Gibbons]], [[Ben Harper]], O'Brien, [[Viveca Paulin]], and The Tonight Show Band to perform the [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] song "[[Free Bird]]".{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=247}}
In his final moments on air, O'Brien stated that between ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', ''[[Late Night (NBC)|Late Night]]'', and ''[[The Tonight Show]]'', he had worked for NBC for over 20 years, and that he was "enormously proud of the work they have done together"; he then thanked NBC for the first time since announcing his intention to quit. O'Brien said his decision to quit as host was "the hardest thing [he] ever had to do".<ref name="Goodbye">[http://www.thewrap.com/ind-column/conan-says-goodbye-thank-you-nbc-and-free-bird-13418 " 'Conan Says Goodbye: A Thank-You to NBC and 'Free Bird' "],''thewrap.com'', Jan. 22, 2010</ref> He praised and gave thanks to his staff, and thanked his fans (specifically those who participated in the Los Angeles rally during periods of heavy rain) for their overwhelming support. He ended the show by offering heartfelt advice to his viewers in his farewell address, stating:
<blockquote>All I ask of you is one thing ... I ask this particularly of the young people who watch. Please don't be cynical. I hate cynicism. For the record, it's my least favorite quality and it doesn't lead anywhere. Nobody in life gets exactly what they thought they were going to get. But if you work really hard and you're kind, amazing things will happen. I'm telling you, amazing things will happen.</blockquote>
Following the taping, the studio set was used one final time for a party thrown by staff. O'Brien's monologue spot from the floor was framed and signed by his staff as a gift, which touched O'Brien.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=248}} 10.3 million people watched the final episode of ''The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien'', a notably high number for live late-night viewing and for a Friday night. The final episode scored a 7.0 household rating and a 4.4 rating in the 18–49 demo.<ref name="Conan's Last Show">Gorman, Bill. [http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/01/28/conan-obrien-dominates-ratings-in-final-live-tonight-show-week/40447 "Conan O’Brien Dominates Ratings In Final (Live) Tonight Show Week"], ''TVByTheNumbers.com'', January 28, 2010</ref> Not only did O'Brien's final show beat all late night competition, it outscored all prime time shows in the 18–49 demo from that night and the night before.<ref name="O'Brien's Final Show Ratings">Seidman, Robert. [http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/01/23/conan-saves-his-best-ratings-for-last-tonight-show/39866 "Conan Saves His Best Ratings For Last Tonight Show"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125055838/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/01/23/conan-saves-his-best-ratings-for-last-tonight-show/39866 |date=January 25, 2010 }},''TVByTheNumbers.com'', January 23, 2010</ref> The network confirmed that Leno would officially resume as host of ''The Tonight Show'' on March 1,<ref name="abc12110-1">''[[ABC News]]'' article: "[http://abcnews.go.com/Business/nbc-confirms-deal-conan-obrien-speeds-nbc-show/story?id=9621682 Conan's Payback: How Much Did O'Brien's Bugatti Stunt Cost NBC?]" – Page 1.</ref> and NBC aired [[reruns]] from O'Brien's time as host until the network began airing the Olympics on February 15.<ref name="tmzrerun">[[TMZ.com|TMZ]] article: "[http://www.tmz.com/2010/01/21/conan-obrien-the-tonight-show-reruns-nbc-olympics/ NBC Gives Conan O'Brien the Reruns]".</ref>
Leno's first ''Tonight Show'' back pulled in 6.6 million viewers, and his margin over Letterman again held for much of the rest of his run until his second ''Tonight Show'' departure in 2014.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=264}} While his numbers were down from his original incarnation of ''The Tonight Show'', "It's as if a collective erase button was pushed", said Robert Thompson, professor of television at [[Syracuse University]], "with the usual suspects back in their usual locations—except Conan is gone."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=264}}
==Impact== [[File:Conan O'Brien performing.jpg|right|200px|thumb|O'Brien performing a cover of "[[I Will Survive]]" on the first day of his tour in Eugene, Oregon.]] According to NBC, if O'Brien continued hosting, it would have been the first year that ''The Tonight Show'' would have actually lost money, which Leno later contended was damaging to the franchise.<ref name="Conan Destructive to Tonight Show">{{cite news |url=http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2010/01/affiliates-executives-screwed-up-tonight-show-leno-tells-oprah.html |work=Chicago Tribune |title=Conan 'destructive' to 'Tonight Show' and media 'unfair,' Leno tells Oprah |date=January 28, 2010 |accessdate=28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100604022845/http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2010/01/affiliates-executives-screwed-up-tonight-show-leno-tells-oprah.html |archivedate=June 4, 2010 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref> This assertion was scorned by skeptical critics as it was calculated that Conan's ''Tonight Show'' would have made significantly more money in advertising than Leno's show did, due to his more favorable youth demographic numbers. Also Leno's larger staff, higher production costs, and higher salary would have by all accounts made Leno's ''Tonight Show'' more costly.<ref>Adalian, Josef. (January 22, 2010) [http://www.thewrap.com/television/column-post/ratings-finish-line-conan-pulls-ahead-dave-13413 RATINGS: At the Finish Line, Conan Pulls Ahead of Dave]. TheWrap.com. Retrieved on December 17, 2010.</ref> O'Brien and Ross also challenged this accusation, concluding that in order for NBC to use such figures, they must have folded in the cost of erecting the new studio/offices, alongside startup costs.{{sfn |Carter |2010 |p=251}} At NBC, most young employees tended to support O'Brien and joined the "I'm with Coco" [[Facebook]] groups; NBC later asked all employees to rescind their membership in any O'Brien-supporting pages.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=250}} Similar action came when any effort to mention O'Brien's tenure was whitewashed from company history.<ref name="gather">Gather.com article: "[http://www.gather.com/viewArticle.action?articleId=281474978034494&grpId=3659174697259616 ''The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien'' Never Existed.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210181853/http://www.gather.com/viewArticle.action?articleId=281474978034494&grpId=3659174697259616 |date=February 10, 2010 }}"</ref>
Gaspin was happy with the settlement, but nevertheless agreed with one of O'Brien's points—that his show had no time to grow: "Could it have grown? Absolutely ... We just couldn't give him the time."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=251}} Zucker, in an interview with Charlie Rose, defended his strategy but noted that both shows were a mistake.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=252}} Zucker, who had known O'Brien since their days at [[Harvard]] and was very close friends with Ross, was very disappointed with how events played out, although he viewed it as necessary.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=253}} Leno, in an attempt to repair his public perception, granted an interview to [[Oprah Winfrey]] on January 25; he stripped himself of any blame for O'Brien's disappointment, noting that it was all about ratings, and also confirmed that he told a "white lie" in 2004 when he guaranteed ''The Tonight Show'' to O'Brien.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=255}} In a reference to a 2007 Super Bowl commercial starring Letterman and Winfrey (the two had feuded for years prior), Letterman, Leno, and Winfrey all appeared in a spot airing during [[Super Bowl XLIV]] in February 2010.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=260}} The ad—Letterman's idea—was the first time the late-night hosts had met since their own 1992 debacle. In it, Letterman and Leno sit on opposite sides of Winfrey watching the game; Letterman deems it "the worst Super Bowl party ever" due to Leno's inclusion, and Winfrey tells him to "be nice", resulting in Leno quipping "Oh, he's just saying that 'cause I'm here."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=261}} The clip stirred a frenzy, with commentators speculating that Leno had been "[[chroma key|green-screened]]" into the picture.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=262}}
Letterman had initially wanted O'Brien to be in the promo as well, but O'Brien firmly rejected it, saying "No fucking way I'm doing that. It's not a joke to me—it's real."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=262}} O'Brien was sure his agreement prohibited television appearances for several months, but gathered NBC would be only too happy to allow him a one-time reprieve for the ad, as it was to improve Leno's image.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=263}} O'Brien, by this point, was planning a live tour with his staff that would take him on the road, and had also created a [[Twitter]] account which flourished (NBC closely monitored the account for anti-Leno sentiments).<ref name="ewtwit">Lyons, Margaret. [http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/02/25/conan-obrien-twitter/ "Conan O'Brien's Twitter debut"] ''Entertainment Weekly''; February 25, 2010</ref> After about one hour online, O'Brien's number of Twitter followers had rocketed past the 30,000 followers of the official Jay Leno account,<ref name="cnettwitter">Matyszczyk, Chris. [http://news.cnet.com/8301-17852_3-10459535-71.html?part=rss&subj=news&tag=2547-1_3-0-20 "Conan joins Twitter, beats Leno in hours"] [[Cnet]]; February 24, 2010</ref><ref name="latwitter">{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2010/02/conan-obrien-twitter-jay-leno.html |work=Los Angeles Times |title=Conan O'Brien joins Twitter and doubles Jay Leno's follower count in two hours [Updated] |date=February 24, 2010 |accessdate=28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706222922/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2010/02/conan-obrien-twitter-jay-leno.html |archivedate=July 6, 2010 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref> and he held over 300,000 followers in under 24 hours;<ref name="chitwitter">{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/ct-talk-celebrities-on-twitter-0226-20100225,0,5349663.story |work=Chicago Tribune |first=Rob |last=Manker |title=Conan, Ozzie and the Dalai Lama: Together on Twitter |date=February 26, 2010 |accessdate=28 June 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306073029/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/ct-talk-celebrities-on-twitter-0226-20100225%2C0%2C5349663.story |archivedate=March 6, 2010 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref> he surpassed the one million mark in May 2010.<ref name="1 million twitter">{{cite news |url = http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2010/05/tweet-this-conan-reaches-1-million-britney-overtakes-ashton-/1 | work=USA Today | title=Tweet this: Conan reaches 1 million; Britney overtakes Ashton | date=May 25, 2010 | first=Ann | last=Oldenburg| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Many speculated that O'Brien would sign a deal with Fox for a late-night program; [[Comedy Central]] and [[HBO]] had also expressed interest in O'Brien.<ref name="bi012210">Business Insider article: "[http://www.businessinsider.com/conan-obrien-mulling-cable-as-fx-usa-comedy-central-hbo-showtime-put-out-feelers-2010-1 Why Is USA Network, NBC's Sister Station, Wooing Conan?]".</ref><ref>[http://www.movieweb.com/news/NErxpxvwq6pAux Conan O'Brien Mulls Post The Tonight Show Options]. MovieWeb.com (January 22, 2010). Retrieved on December 17, 2010.</ref> Fox's deal moved slowly and they eventually withdrew their offer due to station resistance, the daunting financial investment, and opposition from [[Roger Ailes]].{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=266}}{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=268}}
O'Brien eventually signed with cable network [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] in April, with his next program, ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'', set to debut in November.<ref name="foxnewstbs">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2010/04/12/conan-obrien-debut-new-late-night-tbs/|title=Conan O'Brien to Debut New Late-Night Show on TBS|date=April 12, 2010|agency=Associated Press|publisher=FOX News|accessdate=April 12, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100415181151/http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2010/04/12/conan-obrien-debut-new-late-night-tbs/| archivedate=April 15, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The move prompted industry surprise; online blog [[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]] commented that "Conan will now be featured as a lead-in for ''[[Lopez Tonight]]'' on TBS. It's not just basic cable, it's unsexy basic cable."{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=268}} His nationwide comedy tour, [[The Legally Prohibited from Being Funny on Television Tour]], began on April 12 and ran through June 14. A documentary shot during that time, ''[[Conan O'Brien Can't Stop]]'', as well as a May ''[[60 Minutes]]'' interview, prompted some observers to deem him "whiny".<ref name="HRcover" /> ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]''{{'s}} James Wolcott said O'Brien "came off as a peevish straw of nervous energy ... a self-involved chatterbox."<ref name="HRcover">{{cite news|author=Stacey Wilson|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/conan-obrien-tbs-tonight-show-jay-leno-327970|title=Conan O'Brien: End of the Pity Party|date=May 23, 2012|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=February 9, 2014}}</ref>
As NBC could have potentially retained [[intellectual property]] originating from O'Brien's entire 17-year tenure with the network,<ref name="thr11610">The Hollywood Reporter article: "[http://www.thrfeed.com/2010/01/nbc-to-keep-cocos-masturbating-bear.html NBC to keep Coco's masturbating bear]."</ref><ref name="hr11610">''The Hollywood Reporter'' article: "[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3id3e0b71b5f1a6df4b2df779fa18f5e5e O'Brien's NBC departure leaves bits behind]".</ref> O'Brien simply changed names on the tour (turning his character, the Masturbating Bear, into the "Self-Pleasuring Panda").<ref name="rollingstone-review">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2010/04/13/conan-obrien-revives-edgy-late-night-vibe-at-first-live-show/|author=Scott Sepich|title=Conan O'Brien Revives Edgy 'Late Night' Vibe at First Live Show|date=April 13, 2010|accessdate=April 14, 2010|publisher=Rolling Stone| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100417095312/http://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2010/04/13/conan-obrien-revives-edgy-late-night-vibe-at-first-live-show/| archivedate=April 17, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' later reported that retaining the characters was "not a key issue for O'Brien".<ref name="wp12010">{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/19/AR2010011904276.html?hpid=news-col-blog | work=The Washington Post | first=Lisa | last=de Moraes | title=In the Conan-NBC disaster, who's looking out for the staff? Apparently, everyone | date=January 20, 2010| accessdate= 28 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
==Aftermath== ''Conan'' premiered in November 2010 to 4 million viewers, leading all late-night talk shows and more than tripling the audience of its direct competition, ''[[The Daily Show]]'' and ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' on [[Comedy Central]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2010/11/09/conan-premiere-averages-4-2-million-viewers-2-5-adults-18-49-rating/71374 |title='Conan' Premiere Averages 4.2 Million Viewers, 2.5 Adults 18–49 Rating |publisher=TV by the Numbers |last=Gorman |first=Bill |accessdate=2010-11-14 |date=2010-11-09}}</ref> However, ratings quickly fell; by the following fall, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' proclaimed that "TBS's pricey Conan O'Brien experiment is flopping."<ref name="flop">{{cite web| url= https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424053111903639404576514691273411486?mg=reno64-wsj&url=http%3A%2F%2Fonline.wsj.com%2Farticle%2FSB10001424053111903639404576514691273411486.html |title=''Conan'' Falls Flat in Season 1| date=August 18, 2011 |author=Lauren A.E. Shuker |publisher= [[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=February 9, 2014}}</ref> In an effort to bolster ratings, TBS secured the cable syndication rights to ''[[The Big Bang Theory]]'' at a reported US$4 million per episode to serve as a lead-in to ''Conan'' three nights a week.<ref name="Big Bang">{{cite web |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/tbs-multi-million-dollar-plan-224911| title=TBS' Multi-Million Dollar Plan to Prop Up Conan O'Brien's Ratings| date=August 18, 2011| first=Georg |last=Szalai| work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | accessdate=2011-12-24}}</ref> Steve Koonin of [[Turner Entertainment]] stated in 2012 that "Conan is our Mount Rushmore. We've made him the centerpiece of TBS. If success were only about ratings, we'd just run Westerns all the time."<ref name="HRcover" /> ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' credited it with forging "a digital empire, his company's own shows and a young audience TBS hopes will follow him anywhere." The show is currently renewed through 2022,<ref name="ConanRenewal2022">[https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/conan-obrien-tbs-late-night-contract-2022-1202429947/]. ''Variety''. Retrieved May 17, 2017.</ref> which will bring O'Brien to his twenty-ninth year as a late night host. He is currently the longest-running active late night host, and among all late night hosts only Johnny Carson (thirty years) and David Letterman (thirty-three years) have had longer tenures.
Many of the executives involved in the botched transition subsequently left NBC.<ref name="HRcover" /> Zucker was fired by Comcast Executive Vice President [[Steve Burke (businessman)|Steve Burke]], but stressed that Comcast's insistence to install their own team was the reason.{{sfn|Carter|2010|p=279}} Marc Graboff opted to leave his contract early that November, as did Gaspin.<ref name="HRcover" /> While O'Brien admitted in 2012 that he occasionally still felt resentment over the events that transpired, he noted that "I had an amazing partnership with NBC and was very disappointed at the outcome, but I didn't feel entitled to ''Late Night'' or ''Tonight'' or to the TBS show. If you're in this business and haven't experienced profound pain at some point, you're not doing it right. I strongly believe that."<ref name="HRcover" /> He has had no contact with Leno, noting "the odds are we will both leave this Earth without speaking to each other, which is fine. There's really nothing to say. We both know the deal. He knows; I know. I'd rather just forget."<ref name="HRcover" />
In a 2010 issue of ''[[TV Guide]]'', the timeslot conflict ranked #1 on a list of TV's biggest "blunders".<ref>Battaglio, Stephen. "The Blunder Years", ''[[TV Guide]]'', November 1, 2010, Pages 20–21</ref>
A wax likeness of O'Brien that had been commissioned by NBC/Universal from [[Madame Tussauds]] and unveiled during a December 2009 episode of ''The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien'' was quietly returned to the Madame Tussauds museum on Hollywood Boulevard; the figure had originally been intended to permanently reside in the "NBC Universal Experience" theme park attraction.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.upi.com/Universal-unveils-new-Conan-wax-statue/67461260506842/|title=Universal unveils new Conan wax statue |website=UPI|date=December 10, 2009 }}</ref> A remote segment produced a few months into O'Brien's TBS show saw the host humorously reuniting with the wax statue.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2wUTFaHkWlk|title= Conan Checks In On His Wax Figure |website=Youtube|date=January 27, 2011 }}</ref>
On October 5, 2011, O'Brien returned to [[GE Building|30 Rockefeller Plaza]] for a surprise, scripted appearance on ''Late Night with Jimmy Fallon'' to ceremonially retrieve the [[Triumph the Insult Comic Dog]] puppet from the studio after NBC had finally granted him the rights to use the character on TBS's ''Conan''. During the two-and-a-half minute bit, O'Brien and Fallon joked about the controversy when Fallon said, "You were [host of ''Late Night''] for sixteen years. Then what happened?" to which O'Brien laughed and said, "Don't you worry about that. You're a young guy."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/5847216/conan-obrien-surprises-jimmy-fallon-on-late-night |title=Conan O'Brien Surprises Jimmy Fallon on Late Night |website=Gawker |first=Matt |last=Cherette |date=October 6, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720233420/http://gawker.com/5847216/conan-obrien-surprises-jimmy-fallon-on-late-night |archivedate=July 20, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref>
When interviewed by Marc Maron in 2011, O'Brien remarked, "I'm trying to avoid that thing where you get a story in your head that's very clean. I think there are too many people that come up with a very simple story where they're the hero, and they don't learn anything."<ref>[http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episodes/episode_163_-_conan_obrien "Episode 163 – Conan O'Brien"]. ''[[WTF with Marc Maron]]''; April 3, 2011</ref>
During his 2012 appearance on ''The Late Show with David Letterman'', O'Brien made it clear that he held no animosity toward NBC, pointing out that the individual executives he clashed with had departed the network shortly after he did due to a regime change.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZQF5JF06NYM "Conan O'Brien on Letterman"]. ''[[YouTube]]''; May 17, 2012</ref> Indeed, Conan has occasionally shown clips from his NBC shows on his current TBS program with NBC's permission, and the character of Triumph the Insult Comic Dog (owned by NBC) was eventually allowed to appear on the TBS show as well, with Triumph's performer [[Robert Smigel]] explaining that NBC only stands to gain by allowing him to give their property exposure.<ref>[https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/2y9m04/hey_its_robert_smigel_creator_and_handupass_of/cp7kax0/ "Robert Smigel AMA"]. ''[[Reddit]]''; March 7, 2015</ref>
In an interview on ''Piers Morgan Live'', also in 2012, O'Brien acknowledged that in retrospect the plan to architect a transition for ''The Tonight Show'' five years in advance was "absurd," though he noted that he never anticipated Leno's ratings would fall in that interim, as the press had sometimes intimated, and he pointed out that all previous ''Tonight Show'' hosts had departed when they were on top in the ratings. He further remarked that he was happier in his current situation at TBS where he feels "liberated" and can do the material he wants without the baggage of upholding a legacy.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LQMuQK_B1og "Conan on Piers Morgan Live"]. ''[[YouTube]]''; June 25, 2012</ref>
In 2013, O'Brien was the headline performer invited to give remarks at the White House Correspondents' Dinner, and ''The Tonight Show'' controversy was humorously alluded to throughout the evening. During his own speech, President Obama quipped, "I understand that when the Correspondents' Association was considering Conan for this gig, they were faced with that age-old dilemma: Do you offer it to him now, or wait for five years and then give it to Jimmy Fallon?"<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ON2XWvyePH8&t=364s "President Obama at 2013 White House Correspondents' Dinner (C-SPAN)"]. ''[[YouTube]]''; April 27, 2013</ref> O'Brien himself referenced the affair with a joke that complimented President Obama on job creation: "Since [Obama] was first elected, the number of popes has doubled, and the number of ''Tonight Show'' hosts has tripled."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VIgSgLFwEMs&t=92s "Conan O'Brien remarks at 2013 White House Correspondents' Dinner (C-SPAN)"]. ''[[YouTube]]''; April 27, 2013</ref> The ceremony had also opened with a pre-recorded sketch that featured Kevin Spacey as his ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]'' character Frank Underwood, who at one point expresses sympathy toward O'Brien for "that backstabbing Leno."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X7FVYJ6ONXk&t=312s "'Frank Underwood' to Obama: 'Welcome to Nerd Prom' | ABC News Exclusive | ABC News"]. ''[[YouTube]]''; April 28, 2013</ref>
Later that year, O'Brien was chosen to host ''Carson on TCM'', a series that re-aired classic interviews from ''The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2013/06/conan-obrien-to-host-carson-on-tcm-514047/|title=Conan O'Brien To Host 'Carson On TCM'|date=June 5, 2013|publisher=Deadline}}</ref>
In 2014, Leno participated in a ''60 Minutes'' episode focused on the host's second and permanent departure from ''The Tonight Show'' desk. Leno expressed to Steve Kroft that he had been "blindsided" in 2004 when NBC executives asked him to relinquish ''The Tonight Show'' in five years' time, though he admitted that he had accepted the decision with no argument or inquiry. In spite of this and the public remarks Leno had made at the time blessing O'Brien's succession, both Leno and his wife Mavis characterized ''The Tonight Show'' as having been taken from the incumbent host, rather than being something that he had voluntarily surrendered. When Leno explained that he was more willing to step aside the second time due to the considerable talent of Fallon and because "talented people will only wait so long before they get other opportunities," Kroft pointed out that Leno had said very similar things about O'Brien years before. "Well, maybe I did, yeah," admitted Leno before joking, "Well, we'll see what happens."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/jay-leno-on-leaving-the-tonight-show/|title=Jay Leno on leaving "The Tonight Show"|date=January 26, 2014|publisher=CBS News}}</ref>
During a 2015 interview with Howard Stern, O'Brien explained that he prefers to avoid talking about the "craziness," stating that people in show business shouldn't complain, that "no one cares", and that he noticed addressing the topic even in joking response to an earnest question by a guest on his show invariably resulted in admonishments from the media to "let it go." He claimed that even in hindsight he does not regret doing five more years of ''Late Night'' instead of moving to FOX, nor does he regret his incarnation of ''The Tonight Show.''<ref>[https://www.howardstern.com/news/2015/2/26/conan-obrien-like-youve-never-heard-him-before/ "Conan O'Brien: Like You've Never Heard Him Before"]. ''[[Howard Stern]]''; February 26, 2015</ref>
Leno kept ''The Tonight Show'' number one for the rest of his run, until he handed the franchise to Fallon in February 2014. Fallon's credibility with younger viewers and presence online was why NBC instituted the change, which was announced only three years following O'Brien's departure.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/can-jimmy-fallon-convince-america-hes-a-worthy-successor-to-tonight-show-throne-1200581941/|title=Can Jimmy Fallon Convince America He's a Worthy Successor to ''Tonight Show'' Throne?|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=August 20, 2013|author= Brian Steinberg |accessdate=February 9, 2014}}</ref> During the show that aired the day of the announcement, Conan congratulated Fallon, stating, "Jimmy is the perfect guy to do it, and he's gonna do a fantastic job."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nJWxrCpRlgk|title=Conan Wishes Jimmy Fallon Good Luck |publisher=YouTube|date=August 20, 2013}}</ref> While alluding to (and joking about) the 2010 controversy many times over his last few weeks on the air, Leno did not directly acknowledge his nine-month absence from the franchise nor did he mention O'Brien when he delivered his thank-yous and goodbyes as he concluded his second tenure as host. During the February 6, 2014, episode of ''Conan'', however, which aired the same night as Leno's final ''Tonight Show'', O'Brien referenced Leno in his monologue by alluding to NBC's position as the American broadcaster of the [[2014 Winter Olympics]], saying:
<blockquote>NBC has the Olympics. It's a big deal. NBC will finally get to show somebody who is okay with passing the torch. (pause for laughter and applause) I allowed myself one, but it was a good one.<ref name="goodjoke">{{cite web |url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/conan-obrien-mocks-jay-lenos-tonight-show-exit-with-one-good-joke-201472|title=Conan O'Brien Mocks Jay Leno's Tonight Show Exit With One "Good" Joke|first=Nicole|last=Eggenberger|date=February 7, 2014|accessdate=August 7, 2014|publisher=Us Weekly}}</ref></blockquote>
Though NBC had made a considerable effort to scrub any references to O'Brien's brief tenure as ''The Tonight Show'' host both on-air and online, with one former blogger for NBC Sports noting a corporate policy banning any mention of O'Brien,<ref name="ConanBanned">{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsgrid.com/video/conans-chris-christie-hostage-face-sketch-is-gold-as-christie-himself-denies-any-regrets/|title=CONAN'S CHRIS CHRISTIE 'HOSTAGE-FACE' SKETCH IS GOLD, BUT CHRISTIE HIMSELF DENIES ANY TRUMP REGRETS|first=Rick|last=Chandler|date=March 3, 2016|accessdate=March 3, 2016|publisher=Sportsgrid}}</ref> it was acknowledged by the network during the buildup to the 2014 transition from Leno to Fallon. A brief shot of O'Brien walking onto his ''Tonight'' set was displayed in an on-air promo chronicling the franchise's history,<ref name="AcknowledgeConan">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/nbc-unveils-promo-jimmy-fallons-668492|title=NBC Unveils Promo for Jimmy Fallon's 'Tonight Show'|first=Erik|last=Hayden|date=January 4, 2014|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> and Fallon referenced the conflict on his first ''Tonight Show'' episode, when he opened the show by joking:
<blockquote>I'm Jimmy Fallon, and I'll be your host—for now. (pause for laughter) Of course, I wouldn't be here tonight if it weren't for the previous ''Tonight Show'' hosts, so I want to say thank you to [[Steve Allen]], [[Jack Paar]], Johnny Carson, Jay Leno, Conan O'Brien and Jay Leno.<ref name="FirstFallon">{{Cite episode |title=Episode #1 |episodelink= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-VFgiPXisu8 |series=The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon |serieslink= |credits=Michaels, Lorne (Executive Producer) |network=NBC |airdate=February 17, 2014 |season=1 |seriesno= |number=1 |minutes=2}}</ref></blockquote>
Less than a month removed from hosting ''Tonight'', Leno appeared on ''[[The Arsenio Hall Show]]'' on February 26, 2014, as a surprise guest to deliver the news that the revived program had been renewed by CBS Television Distribution for a second season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/jay-leno-shows-arsenio-hall-show-article-1.1703332|title=Jay Leno makes surprise appearance on 'Arsenio Hall Show' to announce show's renewal|first=Don|last=Kaplan|website=[[New York Daily News]]|date=February 26, 2014|accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref> This proved to be premature, however, as Hall's program was indeed canceled on May 30, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/jay-leno-was-wrong-the-arsenio-hall-show-will-not-return-for-a-second-season/|title=Jay Leno Was Wrong: The Arsenio Hall Show Will Not Return for a Second Season|website=Mediaite.com|first=Matt|last=Wilstein|date=May 30, 2014|accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref>
Comedian Bill Maher paid tribute to Leno when he was inducted into the TV Academy, an honor bestowed upon the host in 2014 when he stepped down from ''The Tonight Show'' a second time. A longtime friend of Leno, Maher complained that Leno was "victimized" by the press during the NBC fiasco.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2014/03/jay-leno-julia-louis-dreyfus-bill-maher-amy-poehler-david-e-kelly-rupert-murdoch-brandon-stoddard-tv-academy-hall-of-fame-697582/|title=Jay Leno Reminds Bill Maher Of Israel As He's Inducted Into TV Academy Hall Of Fame With Rupert Murdoch, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, David E Kelley, Ray Dolby & Brandon Stoddard: Video|last=Moraes|first=Lisa de|date=2014-03-12|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref>
In a 2015 interview Leno reiterated his stance that O'Brien's own performance led to his ouster from 11:35 and that he remained mystified by the suggestion that he should have refused the time slot when it was offered back to him, saying "Why? Because Conan and I were good friends? No. At that point ... it's a business decision. I'm sure it could have been handled differently. But I think it was a matter of letting things take its course. If Conan's ratings would have been fine, it wouldn't have been an issue. It wouldn't have come up."<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/theatre-and-performance/qa-jay-lenos-real-talk-on-comedy-conan-and-one-direction/article24119149/ "Q&A: Jay Leno’s real talk on comedy, Conan and One Direction"]. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''; April 24, 2015</ref> In 2017, Leno again absolved himself, instead emphasizing that he kept ''The Tonight Show'' number one after his return. He addressed the longstanding claim that his contract was the more expensive one to break with equivocation: "I mean, if I'm that smart, how did I lose the show in the first place?"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/awards-chatter-podcast-jay-leno-jay-lenos-garage-1016536|title='Awards Chatter' Podcast — Jay Leno ('Jay Leno's Garage')|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2017-11-09|language=en}}</ref>
When he took over ''Tonight'', Fallon insisted that Leno is welcome to appear on the show anytime he wishes, saying "whenever he wants, he's got a stage."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/jimmy-fallon-invites-jay-leno-677326|title=Jimmy Fallon Invites Jay Leno to Be Guest on New 'Tonight Show'|first=Hilary|last=Lewis|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=February 5, 2014|accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref> [[Jay Leno|Leno]] made his first appearance as a guest on November 7, 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/jay-leno-teases-jimmy-fallon-tonight-show-return-article-1.2003790|title=Jay Leno teases Jimmy Fallon during return to 'The Tonight Show' |first=Kirthana|last=Ramisetti|website=[[New York Daily News]]|date=November 8, 2014|accessdate=November 11, 2014}}</ref> although he had previously appeared in a produced ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]'' [[parody]] on August 12, 2014, in which he is revealed as the mystery man who pushes Fallon (as [[Frank Underwood (House of Cards)|Frank Underwood]]) onto the tracks in front of a speeding subway train.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/house-cue-cards-perfect-parody-article-1.1902728|title='House of Cue Cards' on 'Tonight Show' is the perfect 'House of Cards' parody|first=Kirthana|last=Ramisetti|website=[[New York Daily News]] |date=August 13, 2014|accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref> Leno has subsequently appeared on ''Tonight'' several times in the years since.
On February 13, 2015, Robert Smigel appeared in character as Triumph the Insult Comic Dog on ''The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon'' to promote ''[[The Jack and Triumph Show]]''. During the interview, he joked about the conflict to a visibly nervous Fallon. "Listen, we love NBC. NBC ... we kid, you know? NBC will always be the place where Jack and I got our start. And where they f**cked Conan."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gxup-VFuLrQ "Jack McBrayer Struggles to Talk over Triumph's Quiet Reading"]. ''[[YouTube]]''; February 13th, 2015</ref>
On December 7, 2015, ''[[The Daily Show]]'' made reference to the controversy. When former host [[Jon Stewart]] made a guest appearance on the show, current host [[Trevor Noah]] jokingly remarked "Are you here to take the show back? Oh, man, I heard about this in American TV. Are you taking the show back?". Stewart replied, quietly, "Trust me, a thousand times no".
Over time, as the controversy has become more distant, formal acknowledgement of O'Brien's lengthy career at NBC has become more common by the network. In 2017, mention was made of the host in NBC's 90th Anniversary Special, and a display for him (along with all other former ''Tonight Show'' hosts) appears in the ride queue of the ''[[Race Through New York Starring Jimmy Fallon]]'' theme park attraction at [[Universal Studios Florida]]. A plaque on the O'Brien display reads:
<blockquote>In September 1993, Conan O'Brien made his television debut on ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien'' after working as a writer on such television comedy institutions as ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''The Simpsons''. O'Brien's brand of irreverent humor proved to be a hit with the late night audience, including memorable sketches like "If They Mated," "In the Year 2000," and "Triumph the Insult Comic Dog." In September 2004, on the 50th anniversary of ''The Tonight Show'', NBC announced that O'Brien would take over hosting duties from Jay Leno in 2009. While his time as host proved to be short-lived, O'Brien went on to launch a new late night talk show, ''Conan'', on TBS in November 2010. Conan O'Brien remains a true comedy innovator and, at almost 25 years on the air, has enjoyed one of the longest runs of any late night television host.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}}</blockquote>
In conjunction with his 25th anniversary as a late-night host, it was announced that O'Brien, TBS and NBC had come to an arrangement that would allow the entirety of O'Brien’s late night archive (with the exception of musical performances, which posed insurmountable licensing issues), totaling over four thousand episodes, to become available in January 2019 via a state-of-the-art web site dubbed "Conan 25". The launch marks the first time O'Brien's NBC programs have been made legally available since ''The Tonight Show'' conflict.<ref>[https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2018/09/conan-obriens-complete-late-night-tv-archive-will-be-posted-online-in-january/ "Conan O’Brien’s complete late-night TV archive will be posted online in January [Updated]"]. ''Ars Technica''; September 13th, 2018</ref>

[[File:Brazil's fall (The Economist).jpg|thumb|January 2016 cover of ''[[The Economist]]'' magazine about the crisis. The cover depicts then-current president Dilma Rousseff]] [[File:Crescimento do PIB do Brasil entre 2010 e 2016.png|375px|thumb|Change in GDP from 2010 to 2016 in Brazil.{{cite web|title=Economia encolhe 3,6% em 2016 e país tem pior recessão da história|url=https://oglobo.globo.com/economia/economia-encolhe-36-em-2016-pais-tem-pior-recessao-da-historia-21022917|accessdate=6 June 2017}} Growth slowed significantly in 2014 which was followed by two consecutive drops.]] From mid 2014 to 2016, Brazil experienced a severe [[economic crisis]]. {{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/02/michel-temer-signs-security-decree-stem-rio-violence-180216183747559.html|title=Michel Temer signs security decree to stem Rio violence|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-02-16}}{{cite journal |last1=Barua |first1=Akrur |title=Brazil: Yearning for the good times |url=http://dupress.com/articles/global-economic-outlook-q2-2016-brazil/ |series=Global Economic Outlook, Q2 2016 |location= |publisher=Deloitte University Press |accessdate=21 May 2016 |date=29 April 2016}} The economic crisis became coupled with a political crisis in Brazil that resulted in the impeachment of president [[Dilma Rousseff]] and in widespread dissatisfaction with the political system. In 2015, Brazil's [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) fell by 3.9% due to a drop in salaries, restrictions on credit and a rise in the basic [[interest rate]]. In 2016, Brazil's GDP fell by 3.6% with reductions across all sectors of the economy. It was the first time since 1931 that the GDP had fallen in two consecutive years. In 2017 first quarter the economy up 1.4% and the recession had finally ended. {{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-03/08/c_136110450.htm |title=Brazil GDP falls by 3.6 percent in 2016 |author=Mu Xuequan |date=March 8, 2017}} == Unemployment == Before the recession, Brazil's [[unemployment]] rate hovered around 6.8% for most of 2014 and had been generally increasing since February 2015, averaging 8.5% in 2015. The economy lost more than 1.5 million jobs throughout 2015, fueling public discontent against the political establishment and the political leadership of the [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|Worker's Party]] and President [[Dilma Rousseff]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-15/brazil-s-unemployment-jumps-in-2015-adding-to-rousseff-s-woes|title=Brazil's unemployment jumps in 2015, adding to Rousseff's woes|publisher=Bloomberg}} The unemployment rate continued to rise throughout 2016 to finish the year at 12.0%, with 12.3 million people unemployed and an estimated 2.8 million private sector jobs cut over the preceding two years.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-employment-idUSKBN15F1LE|title=Brazil's jobless rate ends 2016 at 12 percent with 12.3 million unemployed|publisher=Reuters|date=1 February 2017}} == Budget deficit == Brazil is currently experiencing a [[fiscal crisis]] and an increasing [[budget deficit]] which, according to Bloomberg, has been "the largest-ever primary budget gap ... as a two-year [[economic recession]] sapped tax collection while expenses grew further." {{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-30/brazil-posts-largest-budget-deficit-for-february-ever |title=Brazil posts largest budget deficit for february ever |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=18 May 2016 }} The government deficit reached 5.8 billion reais (U$1.7 billion) in the first three months of 2016, the widest reported since December 2001. The two-year fiscal deterioration can be explained by the decrease in government revenue from taxes as a result of the recession, while expenses from government have been growing constantly.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-29/brazil-records-worst-ever-first-quarter-budget-deficit|title=Brazil records worst ever first quarter budget deficit|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=18 May 2016}} == Credit rating == This is a table of the credit ratings of the Brazilian economy according to Trading Economics.{{who|date=April 2017}}{{cn|date=April 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Agency !! Rating !! Outlook !! In early 2017, there were already signals that the economy was beginning to recover, however, it was agreed that the process would be long and slow.{{cite web|title=Recuperação da economia brasileira será longa e lenta, aponta 'FT'|url=http://economia.estadao.com.br/noticias/geral,recuperacao-da-economia-brasileira-sera-longa-e-lenta-aponta-ft,70001658076}}{{cite web|title=Recuperação da economia brasileira ainda é lenta, diz presidente do Itaú|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/mercado/2017/04/1876544-recuperacao-da-economia-brasileira-ainda-e-lenta-diz-presidente-do-itau.shtml}} In June 2017, a 1% rise in GDP in the first quarter of the year was reported.{{Citar web |id= periódico|data=2017-06-01|titulo=PIB do primeiro trimestre cresce 1% após oito quedas seguidas |obra=Jornal Nacional |url= http://g1.globo.com/jornal-nacional/noticia/2017/06/pib-do-primeiro-trimestre-cresce-1-apos-oito-quedas-seguidas.html}} It was the first rise of the GDP after eight consecutive falls (two years). {{Cite news|title= PIB do Brasil cresce 1% no 1º trimestre de 2017, após 8 quedas seguidas|url=http://g1.globo.com/economia/noticia/pib-do-brasil-cresce-10-no-1-trimestre-de-2017.ghtml}} Minister of Finance [[Henrique Meirelles]] said that the country had exited the "greatest recession of the century".{{cite |title=PIB sobe 1% no 1º trimestre, após oito quedas consecutivas|url=http://economia.estadao.com.br/noticias/geral,pib-sobe-1-0-no-1-trimestre-apos-oito-quedas-consecutivas,70001821658}} However, economists say that the growth characterizes only the end of the "technical recession" and that it is still too early to claim that the crisis is over, given that unemployment remains high and there's still widespread uncertainty regarding the future of the economy, especially in the aftermath of the recent political scandals.{{cite web|title=PIB positivo é 'saída técnica' da recessão, mas recuperação é incerta; entenda|url=http://g1.globo.com/economia/noticia/pib-positivo-e-saida-tecnica-da-recessao-mas-recuperacao-e-incerta-entenda.ghtml|accessdate=5 June 2017}} == See also == * [[Brazil labor reform (2017)]] * [[Economy of Brazil]] * [[2018 in Brazil]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Government of Michel Temer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2014-2016 Brazilian economic recession}} [[Category:2010s economic history]] [[Category:2010s in Brazil]] [[Category:Economic crises in Brazil]] [[Category:Recessions]] [[Category:Government of Michel Temer]]

China intends to launch [[Chang'e 5]], the first [[sample-return mission]] to the Moon since [[Luna 24]] in 1976, and to test a new generation of crewed spacecraft. Both of these missions will use the recently developed [[Long March 5]] [[heavy-lift rocket]]. India plans to launch the delayed [[Chandrayaan-2]] lunar orbiter/lander/rover in January. Some of the participants in the expired [[Google Lunar X Prize]] plan to launch their private missions to the Moon in 2019, first being [[SpaceIL]] with their [[Sparrow (spacecraft)|''Sparrow'']] lander. The United States are expected to regain crewed launch capabilities lost after the [[Space Shuttle]] retirement in 2011. Crew capsules [[Dragon 2]] by [[SpaceX]] and [[CST-100 Starliner]] by [[Boeing]] are scheduled to fly their demonstration missions to the [[International Space Station]] as part of NASA's [[Commercial Crew Development]] program. [[Blue Origin]] plans to send its own employees on board of [[New Shepard]] for the first crewed suborbital flight in the first half of 2019.{{cite web '''''23 Minutes Over Brussels''''' is a recording of a live performance by [[Suicide (band)|Suicide]] on June 16, 1978, at the [[Ancienne Belgique]] in [[Brussels]], Belgium, while supporting [[Elvis Costello]] and [[The Clash]]. The recording was first released as a promo in 1978,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rateyourmusic.com/release/album/suicide/21__minutes_in_berlin___23_minutes_in_brussels/ |title=21½ Minutes in Berlin / 23 Minutes in Brussels by Suicide : Reviews and Ratings - Rate Your Music|publisher=rateyourmusic.com |date= |accessdate=2013-04-13}}</ref> but remained largely unheard until its release in 1998 with the reissue of the band's [[Suicide (1977 album)|self-titled debut album]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Suicide-Suicide/release/627068 |title=Suicide - Suicide (CD, Album) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-05}}</ref> The recording "gives some indication of the public's reaction to this confrontational duo in their heyday".<ref name="Hear Before You Die Page 386">1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die (2008 Edition)-Dimmery, Robert Page 386</ref>
==Recording== A friend of the band, Howard Thompson, recorded the performance on cassette tape, and it was later released as a flexi-disc insert for a music magazine.<ref>http://www.headheritage.co.uk/unsung/review/641/ Recording notes</ref> In 2000, while [[Mute Records]] was rereleasing Suicide's catalog, the tape was remastered and included as a bonus track for their [[Suicide (1977 album)|first album]]. The entire performance is mixed as a single track.
==History==
Before Suicide even starts playing, booing can be heard from the crowd indicating that they wanted to hear the main act, [[Elvis Costello]], straight away. Suicide is introduced and begins to play "Ghost Rider". Once it ends, there is booing from the crowd. The second song is "Rocket U.S.A". After that, at roughly 9:30, the audience can be heard chanting "ELVIS! ELVIS!". This attitude continues through the third and fourth songs, "Cheree" and "Dance".
The audience becomes more active during the performance of "[[Frankie Teardrop]]". At roughly 19:30, loud applause can be heard; someone steals [[Alan Vega]]'s microphone (a woman at 20:35 can be heard saying "They took the mic"). Shortly afterwards, the music stops and the promoter comes on, warning the audience that if they don't give the microphone back, there will be "no show". Vega joins in, swearing at the audience. After receiving the microphone, he continues to sing "Frankie Teardrop" [[a cappella]]. After even more booing, Vega shouts "SHUT THE FUCK UP! THIS IS ABOUT FRANKIE!". A few moments later, there is rapturous applause as the band leaves the stage.
Later, Elvis Costello played a very short and angry set in which he made no secret of his outrage over Suicide's treatment by the crowd. This incited a riot. The show was cancelled and Vega's nose was broken. The story is detailed in the liner notes of the 2000 re-release.<ref name="headheritage1">{{cite web|url=http://www.headheritage.co.uk/unsung/review/641/ |title=Julian Cope presents Head Heritage | Unsung | Reviews | Suicide - 23 Minutes Over Brussels |publisher=Headheritage.co.uk |date=1978-06-16 |accessdate=2011-12-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jack |url=http://poundforpound.blogspot.com/2008/12/suicide-23-minutes-over-brussels.html |title=Pound for Pound: Suicide - 23 Minutes Over Brussels |publisher=Poundforpound.blogspot.com |date=2008-12-15 |accessdate=2011-12-05}}</ref>
==Recognition== Suicide would only become famous after the peak of their activity was over. During the 1980s and 90s, they were responsible for influencing many bands and shaping genres such as [[industrial music]], [[dance music]] and notably [[electroclash]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} This performance has been called "a record of proof of an innovative band’s struggle with an unreceptive audience" and has been compared to the audience's reactions to [[Electric Dylan controversy|Dylan going electric]]. It also "clearly demonstrates two individuals flying in the face of convention, screaming their guts out to be heard, and failing to make a poignant imprint on the listening audience".<ref name="headheritage1"/> [[Allmusic]] said that "though the (reissues) extra tracks dilute the original album's impact somewhat, they're worthwhile supplements to one of the punk era's most startlingly unique works".<ref>{{cite web|last=Phares |first=Heather |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/r19328/review |title=Suicide [First Album] - Suicide |publisher=AllMusic |date=1978-06-16 |accessdate=2011-12-05}}</ref> In review of their debut album for [[1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die]], [[Chris Shade]] called it a "riotous comedy", and noted that "(their) lack of [[rock 'n' roll]] accoutrements such as a drummer or guitarist often aroused violent reactions in their bewildered audiences".<ref name="Hear Before You Die Page 386"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
