[[File:Maryam, an acid-attacked victim under treatment, Tehran - 28 April 2018 20.jpg|An Iranian acid-attacked woman under treatment in Tehran, pictured on April 2018.|thumb|250px]] {{Violence against women}}
'''Acid throwing''', also called an '''acid attack''',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8576279.stm |work=[[BBC News]] |title=Cambodian victim on her acid attack |date=21 March 2010 |accessdate=23 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325022243/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8576279.stm |archivedate=25 March 2010 |deadurl=no }}</ref> a '''vitriol attack''' or '''vitriolage''', is a form of [[Violence|violent]] [[assault]]<ref name=Karmakar>{{Cite book | last=Karmakar | first =R.N. | title=Forensic medicine and toxicology | publisher=Academic Publishers | location = Kolkata, India | edition = 3rd | year=2010 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XG84ff-WD2YC | isbn=9788190908146 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2011/11/afghan-sisters-hurt-acid-attack-rejected-proposal.html|title=World Now (blog) |work=[[LA Times]] | date = November 2011 |accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-19/news/gl-5793_1_father-and-son|title=Man who threw acid at woman blames 2 others|work=[[LA Times]] | date = 19 March 1992|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> defined as the act of throwing [[acid]] or a similarly [[corrosive substance]] onto the body of another "with the intention to [[disfigurement|disfigure]], [[Mutilation|maim]], [[torture]], or [[Homicide|kill]]".<ref name=11a>{{cite book | last = CASC | title = Breaking the silence: addressing acid attacks in Cambodia |url=http://www.cambodianacidsurvivorscharity.org/docs/breaking_the_silence.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Cambodian Acid Survivors Charity (CASC) |accessdate=3 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219010314/http://www.cambodianacidsurvivorscharity.org/docs/breaking_the_silence.pdf |archivedate=19 December 2013 |df=dmy-all | date = May 2010}}</ref> Perpetrators of these attacks throw corrosive liquids at their victims, usually at their faces, burning them, and damaging skin [[Tissue (biology)|tissue]], often exposing and sometimes dissolving the bones.<ref name=Swanson>{{cite journal | last = Swanson | first = Jordan | title = Acid attacks: Bangladesh's efforts to stop the violence | journal = Harvard Health Policy Review (student publication), special issue: International Health | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | page = 3 | publisher = Harvard Internfaculty Initiative in Health Policy | date = Spring 2002 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060117184047/http://hcs.harvard.edu/~epihc/currentissue/spring2002/swanson-3.php | archive-date = 2006-01-17 | url = http://hcs.harvard.edu:80/~epihc/currentissue/spring2002/swanson-3.php | ref = harv | postscript = . | access-date = 2018-10-01 | dead-url = no | df = }}</ref>
The most common types of acid used in these attacks are [[sulfuric acid|sulfuric]] and [[nitric acid]]. [[Hydrochloric acid]] is sometimes used, but is much less damaging.<ref name="13a">{{cite journal | last = Welsh | first = Jane | title = "It was like burning in hell": A comprehensive exploration of acid attack violence | journal = Carolina Papers on International Health | volume = 32 |publisher=Center for Global Initiatives, [[University of North Carolina]] |accessdate=3 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123191359/http://cgi.unc.edu/uploads/media_items/it-was-like-burning-in-hell-a-comparative-exploration-of-acid-attack-violence.original.pdf|url=http://cgi.unc.edu/uploads/media_items/it-was-like-burning-in-hell-a-comparative-exploration-of-acid-attack-violence.original.pdf |format=PDF |archivedate=23 January 2013 |df=dmy-all | date = Fall 2006}}</ref> [[Aqueous solution]]s of strongly [[alkaline]] materials, such as [[caustic soda]] (sodium hydroxide), are used as well, particularly in areas where strong acids are controlled substances.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-hampshire-29352141 |work=[[BBC News]] |title=Woman jailed for caustic soda attack |date=24 September 2014 |access-date=11 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/acid-attack-accused-is-refused-bail-20090716-dn0f.html |title=Acid attack accused is refused bail |last=Brown |first=Malcolm |website=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=17 July 2009 |access-date=11 October 2017}}</ref>
The long term consequences of these attacks may include [[blindness]], as well as permanent [[scarring]] of the face and body,<ref name=Bandyopadhyay_Khan>{{cite book | last1 = Bandyopadhyay | first1 = Mridula | last2 = Rahman Khan | first2 = Mahmuda | chapter = Loss of face: violence against women in South Asia | chapterurl=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QfLbAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA61 | editor-last1 = Manderson | editor-first1 = Lenore | editor-last2 = Bennett | editor-first2 = Linda Rae | title = Violence against women in Asian societies | pages = 61–75 | publisher = Routledge | location = London New York | year = 2003 | isbn = 9781136875625 }}</ref><ref name=CNN>{{cite news | last = AP | author-link = Associated Press |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2000/ASIANOW/south/11/11/bangladesh.acid.ap/index.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070922210725/http://archives.cnn.com/2000/ASIANOW/south/11/11/bangladesh.acid.ap/index.html |archivedate=22 September 2007 |title= Bangladesh combats an acid onslaught against women |work=[[CNN]]|date= 12 November 2000 |accessdate=13 March 2008}}</ref><ref name=Bahl_Syed>{{Cite book | last1 = Bahl | first1 = Taur | last2 = Syed | first2 = M. H. | title = Encyclopaedia of Muslim world | publisher = Anmol Publications | location = New Delhi | year = 2003 | isbn = 9788126114191}}</ref> along with far-reaching social, psychological, and economic difficulties.<ref name=11a />
Today, acid attacks are reported in many parts of the world, though more likely in developing countries. Since the 1990s, [[Bangladesh]] has been reporting the highest number of attacks and highest incidence rates for women,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Taylor | first = L. M. | title = Saving face: acid attack laws after the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women |url=http://digitalcommons.law.uga.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1474&context=gjicl | journal = Ga. Journal Int'l & Comp. Law | volume = 29 | pages = 395–419 | date = 2000}}</ref><ref name=3a/> with 3,512 Bangladeshi people acid attacked between 1999 and 2013,<ref>{{cite book | last = UN Women | author-link = UN Women | title = Acid Attack Trend (1999–2013) |url=http://www.unwomen.org/~/media/Headquarters/Attachments/Sections/CSW/59/National_reviews/Bangladesh_annexes_Beijing20.pdf | publisher =[[UN Women]], United Nations| year = 2014}}</ref> and in [[Pakistan]] and [[India]] acid attacks are at an all-time high and increasing every year.<ref name="video.nytimes.com"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/07/27/acid-attacks-women-india-survivors-fight-back/486007001/|title=Acid attacks against women in India on the rise; survivors fight back|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en}}</ref> Although acid attacks occur all over the world, this type of violence is most common in [[South Asia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/01/11/acid.attack.fact/|title=Q&A: Acid attacks around the world|website=Edition.cnn.com|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> The UK has one of the highest rates of acid attacks per capita in the world, according to Acid Survivors Trust International (ASTI).<ref>http://www.asti.org.uk/a-worldwide-problem.html</ref> In 2016 there were over 601 acid attacks in the UK based on ASTI figures. Over 1,200 cases were recorded over the past five years. From 2011 to 2016 there were 1,464 crimes involving acid or corrosive substance in London alone. {{TOC limit|3}}
==Motivation of perpetrators== The intention of the attacker is often to humiliate rather than to kill the victim. In Britain such attacks, particularly those against men, are believed to be underreported, and as a result many of them do not show up in official statistics.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Some of the most common motivations of perpetrators include: * Personal conflict regarding intimate relationships, and sexual rejection<ref name="auto">{{cite journal|url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140673610618636/fulltext?rss=yes|title=DEFINE_ME_WA|journal=The Lancet|volume=376|issue=9748|page=1209|accessdate=20 April 2016 | doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(10)61863-6|year=2010|last1=Solberg|first1=Kristin}}</ref><ref name=10a /> * Racial motivations * Sexual related jealousy and lust<ref name="archive.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.kln.ac.lk/medicine/depts/forensic/images/stories/ques_1/chemical_assaults_worldwide.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206231722/http://www.kln.ac.lk/medicine/depts/forensic/images/stories/ques_1/chemical_assaults_worldwide.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 February 2017|title=Wayback Machine|date=6 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * Social, political and religious motivations * Gang violence and rivalry * Attacks against minorities * Conflicts over land ownership, farm animals, housing and property<ref name=Bahl_Syed/> * Revenge for refusal of sexual advances, proposals of [[marriage]] and demands for [[dowry]]<ref name="Bandyopadhyay_Khan" />
Acid attacks often occur as revenge against a woman who rejects a proposal of marriage or a sexual advance.<ref name="bbc.com">{{cite news | last = de Castella | first = Tom | title=How many acid attacks are there? |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23631395 | work=[[BBC News]] | date=9 August 2013 |accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref><ref name=6a>{{cite journal|last=Mannan|first=A.|author2=S. Ghani|author3=A. Clarke|author4=P. White|author5=S. Salmanta|author6= P.E.M. Butler|title=Psychosocial outcomes derived from an acid burned population in Bangladesh, and comparison with Western norms|journal=Burns|date=August 2005|volume=32|issue=2|pages=235–241|doi=10.1016/j.burns.2005.08.027|pmid=16448773}}</ref> [[Gender inequality]] and women's position in the society, in relation to men, plays a significant role in these types of attacks.<ref>{{cite book | last = Various |title=Combating acid violence in Bangladesh, India, and Cambodia |url=http://www.lawschool.cornell.edu/womenandjustice/upload/Combating-Acid-Violence-Report.pdf |format=PDF |publisher= [[Cornell Law School#Institutes and Programs|Avon Global Center for Women and Justice at Cornell Law School]], [[New York City Bar Association|Committee on International Human Rights of the, New York City Bar Association]], [[Cornell Law School#Campus|Cornell Law School International Human Rights Clinic]] and the Virtue Foundation | location = New York |accessdate=16 July 2017}}</ref>
Attacks against individuals based on their religious beliefs or social or political activities also occur. These attacks may be targeted against a specific individual, due to their activities, or may be perpetrated against random persons merely because they are part of a social group or community. In Europe, [[Konstantina Kouneva]], currently a member of the [[European Parliament]], had acid thrown on her in 2008, in what was described as "the most severe assault on a trade unionist in Greece for 50 years."<ref name=kk>{{cite web|url=http://www.focus-fen.net/opinion/0000/00/00/1819/|title=Kuneva case – the most severe assault on trade unionist in Greece for 50 years|work=FOCUS Information Agency|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> Female students have had acid thrown in their faces as a punishment for attending school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/11/03/world/asia/pakistan-acid-attack/|title=Pakistani Taliban target female students with acid attack|author=Shaan Khan, CNN|date=3 November 2012|work=CNN|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> Acid attacks due to [[religious conflicts]] have been also reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://themediaproject.org/article/acid-attack-injures-roman-catholic-priest-tanzania?page=full|title=Acid attack injures Catholic priest|work=The Media Project|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-24088096|title=Catholic priest targeted in acid attack in Zanzibar|work=BBC News|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> Both males and females have been victims of acid attacks for refusing to convert to another religion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.indiatimes.com/news/india/christian-woman-throws-acid-on-hindu-ex-boyfriend-after-he-refuses-to-convert-269758.html|title=26YO Woman Throws Acid On Ex-Boyfriend After He Refused To Convert To Her Religion For Marriage|work=indiatimes.com|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en}}</ref>
Conflicts regarding property issues, land disputes, and inheritance have also been reported as motivations of acid attacks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4329733.stm|title=BBC NEWS – South Asia – Dhaka men in acid attacks protest|publisher=BBC|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/6758023/ACID_VIOLENCE_A_BURNING_IMPACT_ON_WOMEN_OF_BANGLADESH-CASE_STUDY|title=ACID VIOLENCE: A BURNING IMPACT ON WOMEN OF BANGLADESH-CASE STUDY|author=Garph Publication|website=Academia.edu|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> Acid attacks related to conflicts between criminal [[gangs]] occur in many places, including the UK, Greece, and Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en-maktoob.news.yahoo.com/acid-attacks-intensify-indonesia-gang-fights-132345946.html|title=Acid attacks intensify Indonesia gang fights|website=En-maktoob.news.yahoo.com|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-24835910|title=Acid attacks on men related to gang violence, say experts|work=BBC News|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref>
